title: Question 3
content: An ice cube was dropped into a cup of warm water. The weight of the ice cube, $W$, in grams, reduces as the ice cube dissolves in the water. The weight can be modelled by the following function, $W(t)$, where $t$ is the time in seconds after the dissolving starts. $$ W(t) =28(0.98)^t,\quad t\geq 0 $$ - Find - the initial weight of the ice cube. - the percentage of the ice cube dissolving every $5$ seconds. [3] - Calculate the weight of the ice cube remaining after one minute. [2]

title: Question 5
content: In an ecology experiment, a number of mosquitoes are placed in a container with water and vegetation. The population of mosquitoes, $P$, increases and can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 24\times 4^{0.385t}, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $t$ is the time, in days, since the mosquitoes were places in the container. - Find the number of mosquitoes: - initially placed in the container; - in the container after $5$ days. [4] The maximum capacity of the container is $5000$ mosquitoes. - Find the number of days until the container reaches its maximum capacity. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(0) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(0)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 24}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(5) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(5)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 346}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $P(t) = 5000$ for $t$, find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24\times 4^{0.385t} &= 5000 \hspace{1.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.3em} \answer{t \approx 10.0 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 8
content: An eagle is sitting in her nest and scanning the area for prey. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/beb96113-bce6-4e9f-96f9-57c723565e26/eagle.png) The height, $h$, of the eagle above the ground, in metres, is modelled by the following quadratic function. $h(t)=1.8t^2-8.7t+14$, $t \geq 0$ where $t$ is the time in seconds after the eagle begins to move. - Write down the height above the ground of the eagles nest. [1] - The eagle sees a dormouse and swoops down to try and catch it, however, the dormouse runs away and the eagle returns back to the nest. - How high above the ground was the eagle when it turned around and went back to the nest? - How long does it take for the eagle to return to the nest, from the time it left the nest? [4]
markScheme:
- The eagle is initially in her nest, that is at $t=0$. Therefore her height is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      h(0)&=1.8\times(0)^2-8.7\times(0)+14\\
      &=14
  \end{align*}
  $$

The nest is $\answer{14\,\text{m}}$ above the ground.
- 
  - The eagle turns around and returns to the nest at the minimum point of $h(t)$ with the $y$-coordinate being the height above the ground at this moment.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/b14f56e1-7645-4a85-a4f1-c17abecdf0c8/para1.png)


    The eagle was $\answer{3.49\,\text{m}}$ above the ground when it turned around.
  - The nest is $14$m above the ground. By solving $h(t)=14$ we can find the time the eagle arrives back at the nest.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/e5dafd1a-8037-4edf-9ab2-63ad77102b02/para2.png)


    The eagle took $\answer{4.83\,\text{s}}$ to return to the nest.

title: Question 11
content: The average daily hours of sunlight, $S$, during a 12-month period in a particular town is given by the function $$ S(t)=a\cos(bt-180)+d, $$ where time, $t$, is measured in months, $a$ and $d$ are constants, and $b$ is measured in degrees. The graph of $S$ versus $t$ is shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8a6e0bdd-88f9-4d71-8c34-6feeedb1d7e0/images/4284ab68-f212-4ca3-8085-e16d1ab13767/aff649079ad71d825a6dc0770f6728fb76b7cce5.svg) - Find the value of - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Write down the values of $t$ when the average daily sunlight is $10$ hours. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}-S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16-4) \\[6pt]
    % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=6}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}+S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16+4) \\[6pt]
    %   &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(20) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=10}
    \end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $S$ is 12 months. Hence, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &=\dfrac{\ang{360}}{\text{period}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
  & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=\ang{30}}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $S$ versus $t$ shows that $S(3) =10$ and $S(9) =10$.
Hence, the average daily sunlight hours is 10 for
$\answer{t=3\hspace{0.525em}\text{and}\hspace{0.525em} t=9.}$

title: Question 13
content: A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can be modelled by the function $$ P(t) = 50\times b^t,\hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town. - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months. [2] A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough drink and food to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters. - Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster population to reach this maximum. [2]
markScheme:
- Solving the equation $P(1) = 62$ for $b$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times b^1 &= 62 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{62}{50} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.4em}\answer{b = 1.24}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 6$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} P(6) &= 50\times(1.24)^6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 182}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 2000$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times(1.24)^t &= 2000 \hspace{3.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.6em} \answer{t \approx 17.1 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 15
content: The average time, $T$, in seconds, it takes for a customer to find their favourite menu item in an alphabetical menu list can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(n) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1), \hspace{0.5em} n \geq 1,\end{aligned} $$ where $n$ is the number of different menu items in the list. Mehmet visits Taste of Adana Restaurant for the first time to have a lunch. - The restaurant serves $10$ different fresh salads. Find the time it takes for Mehmet to find Persian Salad in the Fresh Salads section of the menu list. [2] - It takes $7.5$ seconds for Mehmet to find Lamb Chops Kebab in the Adana Kebab section of the menu list. Find the number of different kebab dishes served by the restaurant. [2]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(n)$ for $n = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} T(10) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(10+1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.19 \text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(n) = 7.5$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1) &= 7.5 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.45em} \answer{n = 31} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 16
content: The diagram below shows the graph of a quadratic function $f(x) = 2x^2 + bx + c$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f982a52-59ba-4f95-a36a-b780904e0f9b/images/45767584-5045-4282-ac7c-db20e0fb8792/75e0c507b59edc93cc9f79e429c580e90c045817.svg) - Write down the value of $c$. [1] - Find the value of $b$ and write down $f(x)$. [3] - Calculate the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of $f$. [2]
markScheme:
- $\answer{c = -30}$
- The graph of $f$ passes through the point P$(3,0)$.
Hence, using the coordinates of P, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(3) &= 0 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  2(3)^2 + b(3) - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  18 + 3b - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  3b - 12 &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4em} \answer{b = 4}
  $$

  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.4em} \answer{f(x) = 2x^2 + 4x - 30}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The axis of symmetry of the graph of $f$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em}  x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \\[8pt]
  x &= -1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = -1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.65em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) - 30 \\[6pt]
  &= -32\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$\answer{(-1,-32)}$

title: Question 17
content: PM$2.5$ particles are tiny air pollutants with a diameter of $2.5$ micrometres or less. In comparison, the average diameter of a human hair is about $70$ $\text{micrometres}$. Air pollution from diesel & petrol engines form part of PM$2.5$ emissions and of $\text{particular}$ concern due to the health impacts. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/317d2b94-7c4d-4921-822c-e2e52637e72e/images/6e671114-89e5-4a4e-97fd-f26f87bea003/2e913d65859b2219fd828cae63e39f9922b8ba1c.svg) During a particular working day, the rate of PM$2.5$ emissions, in grams per second, from all road vehicles in Beijing, China is modelled by the function $$ E(t) = 6\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}t - \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) + 9, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Find the maximum rate of PM2.5 emissions during the day in Beijing, China.[2] - Find the times at which the maximum rate of PM2.5 emissions occur during the day. [3]
markScheme:
- The max value of the sine function is $1$.
Hence the max rate of PM2.5 emissions during the day is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.55em} E_{\text{max}} &= 6(1) + 9 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ g$/$sec}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $E(t) = 15$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} 6\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}t - \dfrac{5\pi}{6}\right) + 9 &= 15 \\[4pt]
  t &= 8,\hspace{0.25em} 20 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the max rate of PM2.5 emissions occurs at
$\answer{8 \text{ am}}$
and  $\answer{8 \text{ pm}}$

title: Question 18
content: The tip of a large wind turbine's blade rotates at a constant speed on a windy day. Its height, $H$ , in metres, above the ground is modelled by the function $$ H(t) = 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 80, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the turbine was accelerated to its max speed. - Write down the minimum height of the blade's tip above the ground. [2] - Find the height of the blade's tip above the ground after $8$ seconds. [2] - Find the time it takes for the blade's tip to complete one full revolution. [2]
markScheme:
- The min value of the sine function is $-1$.
Hence the min height of the blade's tip is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  H_{\text{min}} &= 52(-1) + 80 \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 28\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $H(t)$ for $t = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} H(8) &= 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 8) + 80 \\[6pt]
  &= 52\sin \ang{480} + 80 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 125\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/345633bb-e844-436b-bd39-eff8642672ef/images/5f3d01f7-4c01-4f77-b034-46af9d83cc7a/279de316931380f9a5da6848695c261465d527a8.svg)


  Hence it takes
$\answer{6 \text{ seconds}}$
for the blade's tip to complete one full revolution.

title: Question 20
content: The magnitude of an earthquake, $M$, on the Richter scale, can be modelled by the function $$ M(E) = \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2, \\[3pt] $$ where $E$ is the amount of energy, in joules, released by the earthquake. - Find the magnitude of an earthquake which releases $6.3\times10^{13}$ joules of $\text{energy}$. [2] The Great Chilean Earthquake of $1960$, the most powerful earthquake recorded in the $20$th century, had a magnitude of $9.5$ on the Richter scale. - Find the amount of energy, in joules, released by the Great Chilean $\text{Earthquake}$. [2]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $M(E)$ for $E = 6.3\times10^{13}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} M(E) &= \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(6.3\times10^{13}) - 3.2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 6.00}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $M(E) = 9.5$ for $E$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2 &= 9.5 \hspace{7.85em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{E \approx 1.12\times10^{19} \text{ joules}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 21
content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular day can be modelled by the equation $$ D = 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/4265cedf-520e-4467-bdb0-2d56bcfc7630/19fd3a817fff397619c38bc3f6d8f3794089c50d.svg) - Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the times when they occur. [2] - A large yacht has a draught of $3$ metres. Decide whether the yacht will be able to enter the harbour at $5$ pm. [2]
markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/ba52a231-78e9-46b9-857b-1237e71c6260/99ad31616997cbd93f3b2bcca5b2e21cec1a56b5.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 6, 18} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4.2em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 7.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 0, 12, 24}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 17$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} D &= 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 17) + 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 2.5\cos 5\ang{10} + 5 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 2.83\text{ m} \\[6pt]
  &< 3 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the yacht
$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $5$ pm.

title: Question 22
content: For $2019$, the income tax rates for a resident in UK are shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/92f945de-d157-4da3-bd84-e9ceb61ac7f4/images/10766b83-e4d8-4b2c-bca4-d3ffad2296e5/b0ad0a092577a73313e3e5cec3d37079a38fab29.svg) - Write down the highest amount of income that is free of tax. [1] - Calculate the amount of tax payable on the first £$50\hspace{0.15em}000$ of income.[2] - Theresa earns £$148\hspace{0.15em}500$ in $2019$. Find the amount of her income tax payable.[3]
markScheme:
- $\answer{\text{\pounds}12\hspace{0.15em}500}$
- Evaluating tax payable for the income of £$50\hspace{0.15em}000$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1em} \text{Tax payable} &= 0 + 0.2(50\hspace{0.15em}000 - 12\hspace{0.15em}500) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \text{\pounds}7500}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating tax payable for the income of £$148\hspace{0.15em}500$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \text{Tax payable} &= 7500 + 0.4(148\hspace{0.15em}500 - 50\hspace{0.15em}000) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \text{\pounds}46\hspace{0.15em}900}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 23
content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular can be modelled by the equation $$ D = 3\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/88525833-f18f-4bc6-8659-178e0c8217ce/bc607b763c6a7abff0abf4c7db110b192240d1a3.svg) - Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the times when they occur. [2] - A large boat has a draught of $2.5$ metres. Decide whether the boat will be able to enter the harbour at $8$ pm. [2]
markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/c2909ae5-a8e9-4c71-8012-36bfe1b65413/5c4bc36227599f18aecea5fee37d5db9b328bd33.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 9, 21} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.35em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 8 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 3, 15}\end{aligned}

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 20$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} D &= 3\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 20) + 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sin 600\text{\textdegree} + 5 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 2.40\text{ m} \\[6pt]
  &< 2.5 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the boat
$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $8$ pm.

title: Question 26
content: A house located in a town experiencing drought issues features a square-shaped roof, with each side being $x$ meters. The roof is able to catch and store rainwater. During a rainfall, it is known that the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected is directly proportional to the square of $x$. It is known that the system can collect $19\hspace{0.15em}845$ litres when the value of $x$ is $7$ metres. - Find an equation for $W$ in terms of $x$.[2] The formula found in part (a) can be used to determine the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected by other houses in the town with a square roof. - Determine the side length of a square roof that has collected $32\hspace{0.1em}805$ litres during a rainfall. [3]
markScheme:
- According to the description we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      W &= cx^2 \\
      19\hspace{0.15em}845 &= c(7)^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      c &= \dfrac{19\hspace{0.15em}845}{49} \\[6pt]
      c &= 405\\[-10pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

Therefore, the formula is $\answer{W(x)=405x^2}$

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- Substituting $W=32\hspace{0.1em}805$ into our equation from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      32\hspace{0.1em}805 &= 405x^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      x^2 &= \dfrac{32\hspace{0.1em}805}{405} \\[6pt]
      &= 81 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}} \\[6pt]
      &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9\hspace{0.15em}\text{m}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 28
content: A Ferris wheel rotates at a constant rate in a clockwise direction. The height of a passenger car above the ground, $h$ metres, at time $t$ minutes, can be modelled by $$ \begin{align*} h(t)=a \sin (bt) + c \, , \hspace{3em}\text{where $a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}$.} \end{align*} $$ ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/01bb276f-eb90-4d9f-80b8-d3071fb7b4e5/images/a13e08ac-86a9-45d8-9793-3dcecb46fb25/ai1056.PNG) When $t=0$, the passenger car is $75$ metres above the ground. - State the value of $c$.[1] The passenger car first reaches its maximum height of $135$ metres when $t=6$. - Find the value of - $a$. - $b$.[3] A ride on the Ferris wheel consists of two full rotations. - Calculate the how long it takes to ride on the Ferris wheel.[2]

title: Question 32
content: The Chicago Wheel, the world's first Ferris wheel, was designed and built in 1893 by an American civil engineer, George W. G. Ferris Jr. The height, in metres, above the ground of a passenger on the Chicago Wheel after $t$ minutes can be modelled by the function $h(t) = 38\cos\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{10}(t-10)\Big) + 42$. - Find the maximum height reached by a passenger on the Chicago Wheel. [1] - Find the height above the ground of a passenger $12$ minutes after the ride has started. [1] - Find the time, in minutes, it takes for the Chicago Wheel to complete one $\text{rotation}$. [2] - Given that passengers only complete one rotation on the Chicago Wheel, calculate how long they are more than $65$ metres above the ground. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{\text{max}} &= 38(1) + 42 \hspace{2.6em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 80 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 12$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} h(12) &= 38\cos\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{\pi}{10}(12-10)\Big) + 42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 72.7 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.1em} h_{\text{min}} &= 38\cos(-1) + 42 \\[6pt]
  &= 4\end{aligned}

title: Question 39

title: Question 42
content: Certain content on the internet can become viral when the content spreads exponentially. The spread of content published by a specific content creator can be modelled by the function $$ N(t)=145 \times 1.25^t, $$ where $N$ is the number of people reached by the content, and $t$ is the number of hours since the content's publication. - Write down the number of people reached immediately after the content's publication.[1] - Calculate the number of hours it takes for the content to reach $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ people.[2] - Calculate the number of people reached after $80$ hours.[2] Approximately $5$ billion people in the world are now connected to the internet. - Explain why the model starts to become unrealistic after about $3$ days.[1]
markScheme:
- The immediate number of people reached can be found when $t=0$.
Hence,

  $$
  \answer{N(0)=145}
  $$

- We solve the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  145 \times 1.25^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  t &\answer{t\approx29.3}\hspace{3em} [\text{using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $t=80$ into the function $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 145 \times 1.25^t \\[4pt]
  N(80) &= 145 \times 1.25^{80} \\[4pt]
  &= 8\hspace{0.15em}206\hspace{0.15em}709\hspace{0.15em}165.19 \\[4pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx8\hspace{0.15em}210\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{The model becomes unrealistic after about 3 days (72 hours) as the output of the model}}$
  $\answer{\text{(number of people reached) starts to exceed the total number of people in the world }}$
  $\answer{\text{connected to the internet.}}$

title: Question 43
content: The most popular mobile phone plans in $2019$ from a major mobile service provider in Australia are summarised in the table below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b75a904d-f2de-4d46-bdc6-b410cc688853/images/6cf3428b-91b5-413a-90f3-ffc1bf9e7a1b/4b6cfffce9db227a1223cd6215b239f9cf62d983.svg) - The total monthly cost, $C$, in AUD, of the Optimal Data Plan can be $\text{modelled}$ as a piecewise linear function of the amount of data, $d$, in GB, used. Determine the model. [4] - Find down the total monthly cost of the Optimal Data Plan if: - $8$ GB of data is used; - $12$ GB of data is used. [3] - Determine how many GB of data is used when the Optimal Data Plan $\text{becomes}$ more expensive than the Massive Data Plan. [2] Daniela is using the Optimal Data Plan and is thinking of changing it to the $\text{Massive}$ Data Plan. It is the evening of December $7$, $2019$ and she has already used $3.5$ GB of data so far. Assume that her data usage continues at the same constant rate during December and the next year. - Estimate Daniela's data usage in December. [2] - Hence explain why Daniela should change her plan. [1] - Find the amount of money Daniela will save each month in $2020$ if she changes her Optimal Data Plan to the Massive Data Plan.[2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{C(d) = \left\{ \begin{array}{lcl}
  39, && 0\leq d \leq 10 \\[6pt]
  39 + 10(d-10), && d > 10 
  \end{array} \right.}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{39 \text{ AUD}}$
  - Evaluating $C(d)$ for $d = 12$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} C(12) &= 39 + 10(12-10) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 59 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $C(d) = 79$ for $d > 10$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} 39 + 10(d-10) &= 79 \\[6pt] 
  d &= 14 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
Optimal Data Plan becomes more expensive than Massive Data Plan
  $\answer{\text{when more than \(14\) GB of data is used}}$
- Daniela's approximate data usage in December is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3.5}{7} \times 31 &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{15.5 \text{ GB}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{Because her current plan is more expensive than Massive Data Plan}}$
- Evaluating $C(d) - 79$ for $d = 15.5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  C(15.5) - 79 &= [39 + 10(15.5-10)] - 79\\[6pt]
  &= 94 - 79 \\[6pt] 
  &\answer{= 15 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 46
content: The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a boating marina on a particular day can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) &= 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the depth of water at midnight. [1] - The cycle of water depths repeats every T hours. Find the value of T. [2] - - Write down the minimum and maximum depths of water during the day. - Find the times at which the minimum and maximum depths of water occur during the day.[4] - Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below.[3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/9f9c68ce-1d0d-4487-a7d2-c9a33bc05e53/65ae508d3aaa92f2c9dd08b381c4298f16693fe9.svg) - A ship with $8$ m draught is allowed to enter the marina if the depth of water is greater than $10$ m. Find the time interval before midday, in hours and minutes, during which the ship is not allowed to enter the marina. [4]
markScheme:
- $\answer{12.5\text{ m}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{T} &= \dfrac{360}{30} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]

Hence the min and max depths of water are

    $$

    &\answer{= 16.5\text{ m}}\end{aligned}

  - Solving the equation $D(t) = 8.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.9em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 8.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 9,\hspace{0.25em} 21 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the min depth of water occurs at
$\answer{9 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{9 \text{ pm}}$
    Similarly, solving the equation $D(t) = 16.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 16.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 3,\hspace{0.25em} 15 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}

    Hence the max depth of water occurs at
$\answer{3 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{3 \text{ pm}}$

- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/3fbc1ff1-c2d9-4c80-a98e-ea0dfbdfbd10/51784b29690fe6ba6b16afe9863a1352814ae7c6.svg)


- Solving the equation $D(t) = 10$ for $t < 12$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 10 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 7.289,\hspace{0.25em} 10.711 \hspace{2.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.289(60) &= 17.34 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]

  Hence the ship is not allowed to
enter the marina
$\answer{\text{between 7:17 am and 10:43 am}}$

title: Question 49
content: The bench press world record weight, $W$, in kilograms, is modelled by the function $$ W(t) = \dfrac{M}{1 + Ce^{-0.04t}}, $$ where $t$ is the number of years that have passed since $1953$. The first bench press world record of $227.27$ kg was set in $1953$. According to bench press experts, the record weight will eventually reach a limit of $350$ kg. - - Write down the value of $M$. - Find the value of $C$ , giving your answer correct to $2$ decimal places. Find the weight that he has to bench press in $2025$ to set a new bench press world record according to the model. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{M = 350}$
  - Solving the equation $W(0) = 227.27$ for $C$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{350}{1 + Ce^{-0.04(0)}} &= 227.27 \hspace{5.6em} \\[6pt]
    \dfrac{350}{1 + C} &= 227.27 \\
    \end{aligned}
    $$


    $$
    \hspace{9.6em} \answer{C \approx 0.54} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
    $$


- Solving the equation $W(t) = 337$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.9em} \dfrac{350}{1 + 0.54e^{-0.04t}} &= 337 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 66 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/515632bd-ef04-40ae-b5cf-41c585276775/images/17a3be18-8a25-4d9c-9902-4ab75a6551e2/3995fc167568b86787ae79ed98ca134320f14178.svg)


  Hence the current unbeaten bench press world record was set in
$\answer{2019}$
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/515632bd-ef04-40ae-b5cf-41c585276775/images/592efbef-223b-4918-a7ee-77220e95126c/00dae124260e7339716684c3dd5812e8ff1deace.svg)


  Hence, evaluating $W(t)$ for $t = 72$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.7em} W(72) &= \dfrac{350}{1 + 0.54e^{-0.04(72)}} \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 340 \text{ kg}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 58
content: The graph of a quadratic function has a $y$-intercept at A$(0,24)$ and one of its $x$-intercepts is B$(2,0)$. The $x$-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is $4$. The equation of the quadratic function is in the form $y = ax^2+bx+c$. - Write down the value of $c$. [1] - Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] - Write down the coordinates of the second $x$-intercept of the function. [1]
markScheme:
- $\answer{c = 24}$
- Using the axis of symmetry formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.4em} 4 &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x = 4$}] \\[6pt]
  b &= -8a \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the coordinates of B, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0 &= a(2)^2 + b(2) + c \\[6pt]
  [\text{from $(1)$ \& part (a)}] \hspace{2em} 0 &= a(2)^2 + (-8a)(2) + 24 \hspace{3.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.1em} \answer{a = 2} \\[3pt] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

  Hence, substituting $a = 2$ in the equation $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= -8(2) \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$

title: Question 60
content: The following table shows the total revenue, $y$, in Australian dollars (AUD), $\text{obtained}$ daily during the first week of January $2020$, by Peppy's Pizza $\text{restaurant}$ and the number of guests, $x$, served. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b8e05a7-0c33-4aef-a8f9-eaa7da8cacbd/images/5c7e3e73-93f7-4332-8ef8-a9fee762c9a8/9736e8eb9c9cfe8a065bfa8f5344721e7887b704.svg) - - Calculate the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient, $r$, for this data. - Hence comment on the result. [4] - Write down the equation of the regression line $y$ on $x$. [2] - Use the line of the regression to estimate the revenue of serving $70$ guests. Give your answer correct to the nearest AUD. [3] Daily maintenance cost for the restaurant is $240$ AUD. Additionally, the cost of serving one guest is $5$ AUD. - Determine if the restaurant makes a profit when serving $45$ guests on a $\text{particular}$ day. [2] - - Write down an expression for the total revenue of serving $x$ guests. - Find an expression for the profit of the restaurant when serving $x$ guests on a particular day. - Find the least number of guests required to be served to result in a profit for the day. [5]
markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{r = 0.991}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
  - $\answer{\text{Positive, strong correlation b/n the number of guests and revenue}}$

- $\answer{y = 10.4x - 14.3}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Evaluating $y = 10.4x - 14.3$ for $x = 70$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 10.4(70) - 14.3 \\[6pt] 
  &= 713.7 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 714 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The profit of the restaurant when serving $45$ guests on a
particular day is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
  &= 410 - (240 + 5(45)) \\[6pt]
  &= -55 \text{ AUD} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Hence the restaurant makes a loss when serving only \(45\) guests.}}$
- 
  - $\answer{\mathrm{Revenue} = 10.4x - 14.3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.4em} \mathrm{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
    &= (10.4x - 14.3) - (240 + 5x) \\[6pt]
    &= 10.4x - 14.3 - 240 - 5x \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 5.4x - 254.3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $\text{Profit} = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} 5.4x - 254.3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 47.1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(48\) guests}}$
are required to be served to result in a profit.

title: Question 65
content: The average gasoline price, $P$, in cents per gallon, in USA $2019$ can be modelled by the function $$ \hspace{1em} P(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t+\ang{90}) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$. Part of the graph of $y = P(t)$ is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/f323592f-678a-4312-aa48-55fd411bb4ce/eba99471e7227e6ca3549b0274fdd498563d4121.svg) - Write down the value of $b$. [1] The average price of gasoline at the end of $14$th of January, $2019$ was $328$ cents per gallon. - Show that the value of $a$ is equal to 56. [2] - Hence calculate: - the average gasoline price on the $14$th of February, $2019$; - the minimum and maximum average prices of gasoline in USA $2019$. [3] The cycle of average gasoline prices repeats every T days. - Determine the value of T.[2]
markScheme:
- $\answer{300}$
- Solving the equation $P(14) = 328$ for $a$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 14+\ang{90}) + 300 &= 328 \hspace{10em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos \ang{300} + 300 &= 328 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.2em} \answer{a = 56} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 31+14 = 45$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P(45) &= 56\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 45+\ang{90}) + 300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 340 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max average prices are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_{\text{min}} &= 56(-1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 244 \text{ cents per gallon}} \hspace{3em} \\[15pt]
    P_{\text{max}} &= 56(+1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 356 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/95fdb075-ae11-4e91-9c51-45fed90c3c09/0189e79cc182a1047199d3fb9dc1b367d698bb2d.svg)


  Hence we find
$\answer{\text{T} = 24}$

title: Question 71
content: The average petrol price, $P$, in cents per litre, in Australia $2019$ can be modelled by the function $$ \hspace{1em} P(t) = a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365, \\[3pt] $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$.
