title: Question 73
content: When a coin is thrown from the top of a skyscraper, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. After $1$ second, the coin is $179.3$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $188.2$ m; after $6$ seconds, $159.8$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] - Find the height of the skyscraper. [1] - Find the time it takes for the coin to hit the ground. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    
    \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
    a &+& b &+& c &=& 179.3 \\[3pt]
    4a &+& 2b &+& c &=& 188.2 \\[3pt]
    36a &+& 6b &+& c &=& 159.8
    \end{array}} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45dabcef-b9ef-4f62-87fe-f37674153ffe/images/3205da83-27aa-4a59-acd7-c2722a0e3a9c/13c88ece23638748c2e63548748180dced5a9e26.svg)


    Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/45dabcef-b9ef-4f62-87fe-f37674153ffe/images/918f55b1-39bd-4ecb-8146-97ebf200d357/8c737a936777a47edd03c6c7de7ba744071b76ba.svg)


    Hence we find
$\answer{a = -3.2, \hspace{0.25em} b = 18.5, \hspace{0.25em} c = 164}$

- Evaluating $s(t)$ at $t = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.9em} s(0) &= -3.2(0)^2 + 18.5(0) + 164 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 164 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $s(t) = 0$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -3.2t^2 + 18.5t + 164 &= 0 \hspace{10.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.5em} \answer{t \approx 10.6 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 75
content: Gordon is cooking steaks for his friends Gino and Fred. When Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, the rate at which the internal temperature decreases can be modelled by the function: $$ \begin{align*} T_1 (t)=ke^{-0.0811t}+20 \end{align*} $$ Where $T_1$ is the temperature of the steak in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after it has been removed from the grill. $k$ is a positive constant. At the time the first steak is removed from the grill, it has an internal temperature of $65^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Find the value of $k$.[2] - State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_1(t)$. Interpret this in context. [2] Gordon wants to let the steak rest until it reaches an internal temperature of $50^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Calculate the length of time the steak should rest for.[2] At the exact time Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, he adds two more steaks to the grill to cook. The rate at which the internal temperature of the steaks increases on the grill can be modelled by the function: $$ \begin{align*} T_2 (t)=180-160e^{-0.0472t} \end{align*} $$ Where $T_2$ is the temperature of the steaks in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after they have been placed on the grill. - State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_2(t)$. Interpret this in context. [2] - Determine the time at which all three steaks have the same internal temperature. [3] Gino wants his steak rare, and so Gordon removes it from the grill after $6.5$ minutes. - Calculate the internal temperature of Gino’s steak when it is taken off the grill. [2] Fred wants his steak well done, which means an internal temperature of $75^\circ \mathrm{C}$. - Calculate how much longer Fred’s steak will stay on the grill after Gino’s is removed.[3]

title: Question 76
content: The graph shows the curve of a quadratic function of the form $f(x) = ax^2 + bx + 90$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6886819b-3fbd-43d3-95f6-61cf97d171c1/images/abf35098-dbcc-4ba6-a3af-f17c013fd694/e02d6931ce58420fa7c9cbe422473aefce55e151.svg) - Write down the equation for the axis of symmetry of the curve. [2] - Hence, or otherwise, find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [3] - Find the $y$-coordinate of the vertex of the curve. [1]
markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry intersects the $x$-axis midway between the
$x$-intercepts.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.15em} x &= \dfrac{-5+9}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.4em} \answer{x = 2}
  $$

- Using the coordinates of A, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-5) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  a(-5)^2 + b(-5) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  25a - 5b &= -90 \hspace{1em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the
coordinates of B, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(9) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.6em} a(9)^2 + b(9) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  81a + 9b &= -90 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system
of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.4em} \answer{a = -2}\hspace{0.75em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.75em}\answer{b = 8}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- The vertex of the curve lies on the axis of symmetry.
Hence, evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} f(2) &= -2(2)^2 + 8(2) + 90 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 98}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 77
content: Radiocarbon dating can be used to estimate the age of an artifact made of wood. Archeologists take a sample of wood from the artifact and measure the ratio, $r$, of Carbon-$14$ in the sample to Carbon-$14$ in a living wood. The age, $t$, in years, is then estimated by using the equation $$ \begin{aligned} \hspace{14.5em} t &= -\dfrac{6000}{\ln 2}\times\ln r, \hspace{8em} [\text{Age Model}]\end{aligned} $$ where $0.01 < r < 1$. A team of underwater archeologists found an ancient wooden shipwreck deep down in the Black Sea. A sample of wood is taken from the shipwreck to determine its age. - Find the age of the shipwreck if $r = 0.75$. [2] In all wood samples, Carbon-$14$ decays over time. If $r < 0.01$, there is insufficient amount of Carbon-$14$ left in the sample wood for its age estimate calculated by the age model to be reliable. - Find the oldest sample of wood for its age estimate found by the age model would just cease to be reliable. Give your answer to the nearest $10\hspace{0.15em}000$ years.[2] - Using the age model, express $r$ in terms of $t$. [2] - Hence find $r$ when $t = 7500$, giving your answer correct to $2$ decimal places. [2]

title: Question 81
content: The half-life, $T$, in years, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned} $$ where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per year of the isotope. - The decay rate of Hydrogen-$3$ is $5.5$ % per year. Find its half-life.[2] The half-life of Uranium-$232$ (U-$232$) is $68.9$ years. A sample containing $250$ grams of U-$232$ is obtained and stored as a side product of a nuclear fuel cycle. - Find the decay rate per year of U-$232$. [2] - Find the amount of U-$232$ left in the sample after: - $68.9$ years; - $100$ years. [3]
markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 5.5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(5.5) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{5.5}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 12.3 \text{ years}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 68.9$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 68.9 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.3em} \answer{k = 1.00\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{125 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 250$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 1.00/100) = 0.99$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=101$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_{101} &= u_1r^{101-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 250\hspace{0.05em}(0.99)^{101-1} \hspace{0.2em} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 91.5 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 82
content: The decibel scale measures how loud a sound is to the human ear. The decibel rating, $\mathrm{dB}$, of a sound can be modelled as a function of its sound intensity, $I$, as shown by the equation $$ \begin{align*} \mathrm{dB} = 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120 \end{align*} $$ Where $I$ is measured in Watts per square metre $(\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2)$ and $I>0$. The pain threshold for the average human ear is $130\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Show that the pain threshold is reached at exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. [1] Amelia has a diesel generator that has a sound intensity of $1 \times 10^{-3.5}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$. - Determine the decibel rating of Amelia's generator. [2] Amelia is considering replacing her old diesel generator and has discovered a quieter petrol generator that has a decibel rating of $50\,\mathrm{dB}$. - Determine the sound intensity of the petrol generator. Give your answer in the form $a \times 10^k$ where $1 \leq a < 10$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2] - Find how many times greater the sound intensity of the diesel generator is compared to the petrol generator.[2]
markScheme:
- Substituting $I=10$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,10 + 120 = 130
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The pain threshold of $130\,\mathrm{dB}$ is reached at a sound intensity of exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.
- Substituting $I=1 \times 10^{-3.5}$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{dB} &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,\left(1 \times 10^{-3.5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &= 85
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{Amelia's generator has a rating of }85\,\mathrm{dB}.}$
- Substituting $\mathrm{dB}=50$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And we know that $0<I<10^{-3.5}$. Using the numeric solver on the G.D.C. we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{nSolve}\big(50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120\,,I\,\big)\,|\,0<I<10^{-3.5} \\[8pt]
  I &= 0.0000001
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The sound intensity of the petrol generator is } 1 \times 10^{-7}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2.}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \dfrac{1 \times 10^{-3.5}}{1 \times 10^{-7}} \approx 3162
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The sound intensity of the diesel generator is approximately 3160 times greater than the sound intensity of the petrol generator.

title: Question 89
content: The downward speed, $V$, in metres per second, of a skydiver $t$ seconds after a jump from a plane is modelled by the piecewise function $$ \begin{aligned} V(t) &= \left\{ \begin{array}{lcl} 60 - \dfrac{K}{t+1}, && 0 \leq t < T, \\[15pt] 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}, && t \geq T. \end{array} \right.\end{aligned} $$ - Show that $K = 60$. [2] - Draw the graphs of $y = 60 - \dfrac{60}{t+1}$, for $t \geq 0$, and $y = 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}$, for $t > 28$, on the grid below. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2df6984d-0273-4410-8b2b-ac32d48ec20c/images/55d9f90c-36a2-4705-a8c9-87a33f526aef/82e862a110791fe827f0532a883ee15963d674c3.svg) - Find the time $T$ at which the skydiver opened their parachute. [2] - Calculate the speed of the skydiver after: - $10$ seconds; - $32$ seconds. [4] Assume that the skydiver's parachute failed to open. - Write down the terminal downward speed of the skydiver. [2]
markScheme:
- Solving the equation $V(0) = 0$ for $K$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  60 - \dfrac{K}{0+1} &= 0 \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
  60 - K &= 0 \\  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.3em} \answer{K = 60} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we draw the graphs of $y = 60 - \dfrac{60}{t+1}$, for $t \geq 0$,
and $y = 12 + \dfrac{46}{t-28}$, for $t > 28$, on the grid below, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2df6984d-0273-4410-8b2b-ac32d48ec20c/images/3273e4d6-3871-4a0c-a24a-35721999c286/f1e6feb2dcd8269a36b82b80c11b2c1941011f79.svg)


- The piecewise function $V$ must be continuous at $T$.
Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.1em} 60 - \dfrac{60}{T+1} &= 12 + \dfrac{46}{T-28} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.15em} \answer{T = 29 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  $$

  Note that the value of $T$ is the
$x$-coordinate of the point A$(29,58)$ from part (b).
- 
  - Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 10$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9em} V(10) &= 60 - \dfrac{60}{10+1} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $t = 10 < T = 29$}] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 54.5 \text{ m sec$^{-1}$}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 32$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{9.4em} V(32) &= 12 + \dfrac{46}{32-28} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $t = 32 > T = 29$}] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 23.5 \text{ m sec$^{-1}$}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- $\answer{60 \text{ m sec\(^{-1}\)}}$

title: Question 92
content: A loaf pan is made in the shape of a cylinder. The pan has a diameter of $24$ cm and a height of $5$ cm. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aaafe79-56c4-4a37-b409-43676a3d5eed/images/855b65c5-7644-44f9-a953-a91912965eb3/a347288bee589088e6dce052611dad40b73c72e7.svg) - Calculate the volume of this pan. [3] Gloria prepares enough bread dough to exactly fill the pan. The dough was in the shape of a sphere. - Find the radius of the sphere in cm, correct to one decimal place. [4] The bread was cooked in a hot oven. Once taken out of the oven, the bread was left in the kitchen. The temperature, $T$, of the bread, in degrees Celsius, $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, can be modelled by the function $$ T(t) = a\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0, $$ where $a$ is a constant and $t$ is the time, in minutes, since the bread was taken out of the oven. When the bread was taken out of the oven its temperature was $205$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Find the value of $a$. [2] - Find the temperature that the bread will be $10$ minutes after it is taken out of the oven. [2] The bread can be eaten once its temperature drops to $35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. - Calculate, to the nearest minute, the time since the bread was taken out of the oven until it can be eaten. [3] - In the context of this model, state what the value of $21$ represents. [1]
markScheme:
- Using the volume of a cylinder formula with $r = 12$ and $h = 5$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.05em} V_{\text{pan}} &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  &= \pi(12)^2(5) \\[6pt]
  &= 720\pi \qref{(1)}  \\[6pt]
  &=2261.9...\\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 2260 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the volume of a sphere formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} V_{\text{dough}} &= V_{\text{pan}} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3 &= 720\pi \hspace{3em} [\text{from  $(1)$}] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $r$, we obtain

  $$
  \hspace{12.9em} \answer{r \approx 8.1 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(0) = 205$ for $a$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times(1.51)^0 + 21 &= 205 \hspace{5.65em} \\[6pt]
  a + 21 &= 205 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{a = 184}
  $$

- Evaluating $T(t)$ for $t=10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} T(10) &= 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{10}{3}} + 21 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 67.6 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(t) = 35$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21 &= 35 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 18.8 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.8em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ minutes}}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{\(21\) is the room  temperature of the kitchen}}$

title: Question 93
content: A factory produces bars in the shape of a cuboid, with a fixed height of $30$ cm and varying base. The area, $A$, of each bar base is described by the function $$ \begin{aligned} A(x) &= x(40 - x), \hspace{0.5em} 5 \leq x \leq 35,\end{aligned} $$ where $x$ is the length of the bar base in centimetres. - Bar P has a length of $10$ cm. Find the volume of P. [2] - Bar Q has the same volume as bar P, however has a different length. Find the length of Q. [2] - Find the value of $x$ that makes the bar's volume a maximum, and state this maximum volume. [2]
markScheme:
- The volume of a bar with base length $x$ cm
is given by the function

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.95em} V(x) &= A(x)\times h \\[7pt]
  &= x(40-x)(30) \\[6pt]
  &= 1200x - 30x^2 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, evaluating $V(x)$ for
$x = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.85em} V(10) &= 1200(10) - 30(10)^2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9000 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(x) = 9000$ for $x \neq 10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1200x - 30x^2 &= 9000 \hspace{6.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.85em} \answer{x = 30 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = V(x)$, for $5 \leq x \leq 35$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4b969d0-4df7-4184-8874-c1e566eb036b/images/590e9d59-33f3-47b2-8b53-31174f419f04/862b3de66152091d457aa4678f6ddd98efb4d6c4.svg)


  Hence the maximum volume is
$\answer{12\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ cm}^3}$
and it occurs when
$\answer{x = 20 \text{ cm}}$

title: Question 96
content: The temperature, $T$, in degrees Celsius, in Istanbul during a particular winter day is modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(t-c))+d, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \end{aligned} $$ where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. The graph of $T$ versus $t$ is shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb0e5137-6e45-4694-89d8-210a316e08af/images/0d3b5230-b966-4d6e-bcd2-b7caf84d141a/6960bc2052fe8ed1bdd6d4f86c2a3bd840872a33.svg) The lowest temperature was recorded at $3$:$30$ am and the highest $\text{temperature}$ was recorded at $3$:$30$ pm. - Write down the value of: - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Find the smallest possible value of $c$, given $c > 0$. [2] The temperature, $T$, in degrees Celsius, in Istanbul during a particular summer day is modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= 5\sin\hspace{0.1em}(0.262\hspace{0.1em}(t-8))+25, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Find the time, in hours and minutes, when the temperature: - reaches its maximum; - first drops below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. [5] - The temperature is below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ for $h$ hours and $m$ minutes. Find the value of $h$ and the value of $m$.[2]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{10 - 2}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} + T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{10 + 2}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 6}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $T$ is $24$ hours.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{24} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.262}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The max temperature occurs at $3$:$30$ pm ($t = 15.5$) and the mean
temperature occurs $6$ hours earlier.
  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.75em} t_{\text{max}} &= t_{\text{mean}} + 6 \\[6pt]
  15.5 &= c + 6 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{c = 9.5} \hspace{0.5em}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $T$ versus $t$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fb0e5137-6e45-4694-89d8-210a316e08af/images/2c85c575-3b76-42dc-84dd-5dda2f5b1cfd/22498aef2f9240c0f54bbcd77edc60575ac3345f.svg)


  
  - If we write $0.995$ hour in whole minutes, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1em} 0.995(60) &= 59.7 \\[6pt]
    &\approx 60 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the temperature
reaches maximum at
$\answer{\text{\(2\):\(00\) pm}}$
  - If we write $0.759$ hour in whole minutes, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1em} 0.759(60) &= 45.54 \\[6pt]
    &\approx 46 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the temperature
first drops below $24$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ at
$\answer{\text{\(8\):\(46\) pm}}$

- Using the $x$-coordinates of B and C, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24 - (20.759-7.231) &= 10.472 \text{ hours} \hspace{1.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we write $0.472$ hour in whole minutes, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.3em} 0.472(60) &= 28.32 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 28 \text{ minutes}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{h = 10}$
and  $\answer{m = 28}$

title: Question 97
content: A right cylinder has height $h$ mm and diameter $x$ mm. The volume of this cylinder is equal to $45$ mm$^3$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/efc9fbc4-0075-415f-b8c9-1a1def8352df/9aebb1d3e12c9fb1c552ed279ae0c28d1ca125c3.svg) The total surface area, $A$, of the cylinder can be expressed as $A = \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{k}{x}$. - Find the value of $k$. [4] - Find the value of $x$ that makes the total surface area a minimum. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the volume of a right cylinder formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  45 &= \pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2\hspace{-0.2em}h \\[3pt]
  45 &= \dfrac{\pi x^2h}{4} \\[6pt]
  h &= \dfrac{180}{\pi x^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total surface area is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= [\text{top \& bottom area}] + [\text{curved surface area}] \\[16pt]
  &=  2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh \\[9pt]
  &= 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2 + 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{180}{\pi x^2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{180}{x}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{k = 180}$
- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$, for $x > 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/70443638-b03e-4b02-9371-621e475b9a63/10ad2caa42e46f8e9db41f9ae6642694c0b81ac1.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{x \approx 3.86 \text{  mm}}$
makes the total surface area a minimum.

title: Question 98
content: The distance travelled, $d$, in meters, of a freely falling object is proportional to the square of the time of the fall, $t$, in seconds. A football dropped from the top of a school building falls a distance of $19.6\text{ m}$ in the first $2$ seconds. - Show that $d(t)=4.9t^2$. [2] - Sketch the curve of $d$ for $t>0$, clearly showing the point $(2,19.6)$. [2] The distance covered, $s$, in meters, by a quad-copter drone undertaking a vertical landing can be modelled by $s(t) = 8t$, where $t$ is the time in seconds after the landing commences. The football is dropped at the same time as the drone commences a landing from the same height of the school building. The football covers more distance than the drone when $t>p$. - Find the value of $p$. [2]
markScheme:
- Since $d$ varies proportionally with the square of $t$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d&=kt^2 \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have
$d=19.6 \text{ m}$ when $t=2\text{ s}$. We can use these to find
$k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19.6 &= k(2)^{2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=4.9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{-7em}\answer{d=4.9t^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ for $t>0$, as
shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/14d89890-1629-4583-8dca-99e74de71942/523fcfa1c1e8c9a28b03f2d2499ceebab285f5d8.svg)


- The curves of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ and $s(t)=8t$ are plotted on the graph
below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/ff8238cb-8231-4138-b80c-2159b3626395/f8c3444e7186ece84caeb418dfee107029e62cc6.svg)


  From the graph, $d(t) > s(t)$ when $t>1.63$. Hence,
$\answer{p=1.63}$

title: Question 99
content: The security personnel at the entry of a rural campground activate a siren to alert campers when a wild animal is spotted nearby. The sound intensity, $I$, of the siren varies inversely with the square of the distance from the siren, $d$. When initially testing the siren, the security personnel found that at a distance of $3$ metres from the siren, the sound intensity is $5$ watts per square metre $(\text{Wm}^{-2})$. - Show that $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$. [2] - Sketch the curve of $I$ for $d>0$, labelling the point $(3,5)$. [2] The campers can only hear the siren if the sound intensity at their location is greater than $1.2\times10^{-5} \text{Wm}^{-2}$. - Find the minimum distance, in kilometers, from the siren where the campers can no longer hear the siren. [2]
markScheme:
- Since $I$ varies inversely with the square of $d$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I&=\dfrac{k}{d^2} \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have $I=5 \text{ Wm}^{-2}$ when $d=3\text{ m}$. We can use these to find $k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 &= \dfrac{k}{3^2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=45\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tcbhighmath{I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$ for $d>0$, as shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/151224cf-2f80-4345-b68e-a612caa31abb/images/612a624d-0502-474e-802f-6124a743e115/AI875.PNG)


- Campers can only hear the siren when $I>1.2\times 10^{-5}$. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I &> 1.2\times 10^{-5} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{d^2} &> 1.2\times 10^{-5}\\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}&>d^2\\[6pt]
  d &< \sqrt{\dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}}\\[6pt]
  d &< 1936.49\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the minimum distance from the siren is $\answer{1.94 \text{ km}}$

title: Question 100
content: The mean depth, $D$, in metres, of a mountain lake fluctuates in a yearly cycle and can be modelled by the function $$ D(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(k t) + b, $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in months, since the beginning of an autumn season. The mean depth of the lake on month $1$ is $33.2$ m and on month $5$ is $22.8$ m. - Find the value of $k$, in degrees. [2] - Set up a pair of equations and find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. Give your answers correct to the nearest integer. [3] - Hence find the mean depth of the lake on month $8$. [2] - Draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for one full year, indicating clearly the minimum and maximum points. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/650b6656-5f6c-4fd2-980c-ceab4bbe6228/22e9fb4574cbc4ff36d7eb0e402d77e50876a875.svg) - Determine the total amount of time in one year that the mean depth is expected to be lower than 26 metres. [2]
markScheme:
- The period of $D$ is $12$ months.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \ang{30}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(1) &= 33.2 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 1) + b &= 33.2 \\[6pt]
  0.866a + b &= 33.2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(5) &= 22.8 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 5) + b &= 22.8 \\[6pt]
  -0.866a + b &= 22.8 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.8em} \answer{a \approx 6} \hspace{1em}\text{ and }\hspace{1em} \answer{b \approx 28} \hspace{3.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 8$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(8) &= 6\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times8) + 28 \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max mean depths of the lake during the year are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.2em} D_{\text{min}} &= 6(-1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 22 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0.5)12 = 9] \\[15pt]
  D_{\text{max}} &= 6(+1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 34 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0)12 = 0\hspace{0.25em}\&\hspace{0.25em}t = (1)12 = 12]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for
$0 \leq t \leq 12$, indicating the points A$(0,34)$, B$(12,34)$ and
C$(6,22)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/2b12daf7-2a64-4082-be83-d94cf2bb913d/73e28209b510fb17f449ac18e686993a5d03e3ef.svg)


- Adding the graph of $y=26$ to our solution from part (d), we can find the points of intersection:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/afc9ddca-9147-42e2-83ce-681f27150723/ai177a.PNG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
  8.351-3.649 &= 4.702
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The mean depth of the lake is lower than $26$ metres for approximately $\answer{\text{$4.70$ months.}}$

title: Question 104
content: Alexandros monitors the temperature during a particular day in Athens. The table below shows some of his findings. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000aea6e-7d28-4e46-a9b8-b0aa808a7144/images/84e35a2c-c6d5-4386-b2a4-aeae6e3c1d12/063047b1151b8885e1ce8bf5005a5b210fdafca9.svg) Based on his observations, Alexandros concludes that the temperature, $T$, in $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, during the day can be modelled by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} T &= a\sin\hspace{0.1em}(b\hspace{0.1em}(t-c)) + d, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight. - Write down the value of: - $a$; - $d$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] - Find the smallest possible value of $c$, given $c > 0$. [2] - Find the time, in hours and minutes, when the temperature first reaches $35\text{\textdegree{C}}$ during the day. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} a &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} - T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{39.2 - 25.4}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 6.9}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} d &= \dfrac{T_{\text{max}} + T_{\text{min}}}{2} \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{39.2 + 25.4}{2} \\[10pt]
    &\answer{= 32.3}\end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $T$ is $24$ hours.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= \dfrac{2\pi}{24} \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.262}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The max temperature occurs at $4$:$12$ pm ($t = 16.2$) and the mean
temperature occurs $6$ hours earlier.
  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.75em} t_{\text{max}} &= t_{\text{mean}} + 6 \\[6pt]
  16.2 &= c + 6 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{c = 10.2}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of
$T = 6.9\sin\hspace{0.1em}(2.62\hspace{0.1em}(t-10.2)) + 32.3$
versus $t$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000aea6e-7d28-4e46-a9b8-b0aa808a7144/images/b598813c-3dbe-453d-be50-5744baac0524/be78b702b9ccf256126ee3383eee8affe77f9461.svg)


  If we write $0.735$ hour in whole minutes, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.735(60) &= 44.1 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 44 \text{ minutes} \hspace{0.65em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
temperature first reaches $35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$ during the
day at
$\answer{\text{\(11\):\(44\) am}}$

title: Question 105
content: The sound intensity level (SIL), $L$, in decibels (dB), of the sound intensity, $I$, in watts per square meter, is given by the equation $$ \begin{aligned} L &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I}{I_0}\right),\end{aligned} $$ where $I_0$ is the reference sound intensity. - Two sounds have intensities $I_1$ and $I_2$ with $I_1 < I_2$. Show that the difference in SIL between the two sounds is $\triangle L = 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right)$. [3] - A train rumble has the SIL of $82$ dB and a dishwasher noise has the SIL of $52$ dB. Find the number of times the train rumble is more intense than the dishwasher noise. [3] Jack is attending a rock concert where the SIL of the music reaches $110$ dB. During the concert, Jack's mom calls him to find out if he is safe and everything is going well. The SIL of his cell phone ring is $70$% of the SIL of the rock music. - The perceived loudness of a sound doubles for every $10$ dB increase in SIL. - Write down the SIL of Jack's cell phone ring. - Jack perceives the rock music $k$ times as loud as his cell phone ringing. Find the value of $k$, giving your answer correct to $3$ significant figures. - Hence, decide whether Jack's mom will reach him during the concert if Jack carries his cell phone in the pocket and turned vibrating alert off. [5]
markScheme:
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.3em} \triangle L  &= L_2 - L_1 \\[6pt]
  &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0}\right) - 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right) \\[6pt]
  &= 10\left[\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0}\right) - \log\left(\dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right)\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_0} \div \dfrac{I_1}{I_0}\right) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we let $I_1$ and $I_2$ be the intensities of the dishwasher noise
and the train rumble, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \triangle L &= 82 - 52 \\[10pt]
  \hspace{1.3em} 10\log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right) &= 30 \hspace{3em} [\text{by part (a)}] \\[5pt]
  \log\left(\dfrac{I_2}{I_1}\right) &= 3 \\[5pt]
  10^3 &= \dfrac{I_2}{I_1} \\[10pt]
  I_2 &= 1000I_1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the train rumble is
$\answer{1000 \text{ times}}$
more intense than the dishwasher noise.
- 
  - The SIL of Jack's cell phone ring is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    L &= 110(0.70) \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 77 \text{ dB}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{\triangle L}{10} &= \dfrac{110 - 77}{10} \hspace{2.9em} \\[6pt]
    &= 3.3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    k &= 2^{3.3} \\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx 9.85} \hspace{3.9em}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Jack's mom will not reach him during the concert b/c the rock music is too loud to hear cell phone ringing

title: Question 106
content: Peter wants to reach a rock, located $5$ km away from his current position, using the strategy outlined below. Every hour Peter approaches the rock by a fixed percent of the remaining distance to the rock. The distance, $D$, in kilometres, Peter has travelled from his original position, can be modelled by the exponential function $$ \begin{aligned} D(t) = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big), \hspace{0.5em} t\geq 0, \end{aligned} $$ where $t$ is the time, in hours, since Peter started moving. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/f49c99b3-6084-4cce-b203-48eef7cf3293/819ba2cfeb3383629fe25649fde3301bcf8c76d4.svg) - Explain why $a= 5$. [2] - Find the value of $b$. [2] After one hour, the distance from Peter to the rock is $3.75$ km. - Find the value of $k$. [2] - Find the distance between Peter and the rock after $4$ hours. [2] Peter can be heard when shouting from $200$ metres away. - Calculate the time it takes until someone standing on the rock can hear Peter shouting. Round your answer correct to the nearest hour. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/749982c8-e46c-4506-bf93-4534155f5e67/284ba0b0f6db44c91e038d4ec5486789b5846da8.svg)


  On the other hand, we know Peter will not travel more than
$5$ km.
  Hence we must have $a = 5$.
- Solving the equation $D(0) = 0$ for $t$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 0 \hspace{1.6em} \\[6pt]
  5 + b &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{b = -5}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(1) = 5 - 3.75 = 1.25$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 - 5\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 1.25 \hspace{2.35em} \\[10pt]
  5 - \dfrac{5}{k} &= \dfrac{5}{4} \\[6pt]
  1 - \dfrac{1}{k} &= \dfrac{1}{4} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{k = \dfrac{4}{3}}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} D(4) &= 5 - 5\hspace{-0.15em}\left(\dfrac{4}{3}\right)^{-4} \\[6pt]
  &\approx 3.42\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the distance between Peter and
the rock after $4$ hours is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5  - D(4) &= 5 - 3.42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1.58 \text{ km}} \hspace{1.4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 5 - 0.2 = 4.80$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} 5 - 5\big(k^{-t}\big) &= 4.80 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 11.2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{11 \text{ hours}}$
until someone on the rock can hear Peter shouting.

title: Question 108
content: Grace is planning on making a 3D printed model of a well-known hill in her local area. She knows that the hill itself is approximately $400$ metres wide and $200$ metres high. A cross-section of the hill is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cfe367d7-cb6b-4d07-9047-93411b82d289/images/2db6ab35-c4bc-460a-be02-e3598d5f4f04/1198a.JPG) Grace plans to model the cross-section of the hill using a piecewise function, $f(x)$, consisting of a first function, $f_1(x)$ for $0 \leq x \leq 200$ and a second function, $f_2(x)$ for $200 < x \leq 400$. For the first section, Grace decides on a logistic function of the form $$ \begin{align*} f_1(x) &= \dfrac{202}{1+Ce^{-kx}} \text{ , where } C,k>0 \end{align*} $$ A point approximately halfway up the hill has coordinates $(100,120.684)$. Using these coordinates, Grace makes the equation $$ \begin{align*} C &= 0.6738\,e^{100k} \end{align*} $$ The summit of the hill has approximate coordinates $(200,201.087)$. - Using these coordinates, find a second expression for $C$ in terms of $k$. [3] - Hence find the value of $C$ and the value of $k$. [3] For the second section, Grace creates a function $f_2(x)$, which she finds by performing the following two transformations on $f_1(x)$ in order: $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ A reflection in the $y$-axis; $\hspace{2em}\bullet$ A translation of $400$ units in the direction of the positive $x$-axis. - Write a complete expression for $f_2(x)$. [3] - Hence write $f(x)$ as a piecewise function. [1] Grace wants her 3D printed model to be of scale $1:2\,000$. This is equivalent to applying both a vertical stretch and horizontal stretch of scale factor $\frac{1}{2\,000}$ to her piecewise function. - Write a piecewise function for Grace's model, $g(x)$. [4] To determine the volume of plastic she requires for her 3D printed model, Grace finds the volume generated when $g(x)$ is rotated $\bm{180^{\circ}}$ about the $x$-axis. - Determine the volume of plastic Grace will require.[3]

title: Question 110
content: John operates a small clothing factory that manufactures jeans. John observes that the weekly total production cost, $C$, in Australian dollars (AUD), and the number of jeans produced per week, $N$, can be related by the equation $$ C = aN^b + K, $$ where $a,b$ and $K$ are positive constants. John estimates that the weekly total fixed cost of $\text{operating}$ the $\text{factory}$ is $7500$ AUD. - Write down the value of $K$. [1] After analysing the financial accounting records of a particular month, John finds the data given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/879f95c0-4366-46af-9667-a1ccca321eee/fbdd8eb79d6d3959b803e0d70b8e5774db6d8585.svg) - Draw a scatter diagram of $\ln(C-K)$ versus $\ln N$, scaling and shifting the axes if needed. [4] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] - Write down the equation of the regression line of $\ln(C-K)$ on $\ln N$. [2] - Hence find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] John wants to increase the production rate of jeans up to $1000$ pairs per week. - Using John's equation, estimate the weekly total cost of producing $1000$ jeans.[2] - State whether it is valid to use John's equation to estimate the weekly total cost of producing $1000$ jeans. Give a reason for your answer. [1] - - Describe how the data must be entered into your G.D.C. to determine John's equation using power regression method. - Hence verify your answers to part (e). [4]
markScheme:
- $\answer{7500}$
- Calculating the values of $\ln N$ and $\ln(C-7500)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/f919f4c4-0ab8-4082-b3a5-15f4da729b49/42ab6379e4ab4c55ae6f463560051439ba03d313.svg)


  Hence, if we draw a scatter diagram of $\ln(C-7500)$ versus $\ln N$,
we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/a09fc063-5ba5-4f42-b9b2-3fd0bef02a7d/59f5b36505be1f8ae52acc1dbbb0c27f31c1e5d3.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- $\answer{\ln(C-7500) = 0.806\ln N + 5.14}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \ln(C-7500) &= 0.806\ln N + 5.14 \\[6pt]
  \ln(C-7500) &= \ln N^{0.806} + \ln e^{5.14} \\[6pt]
  \ln(C-7500) &= \ln (171N^{0.806}) \hspace{3em} [e^{5.14} \approx 171] \\[6pt]
  C - 7500 &= 171N^{0.806} \\[6pt]
  C &= 171N^{0.806} + 7500\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 171}$
and  $\answer{b = 0.806}$
- Evaluating $C$ when $N = 1000$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} C &= 171(1000)^{0.806} + 7500 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 52\hspace{0.15em}300 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{Not valid, \(N = 1000\) is not within the range of the given data}}$
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    C &= aN^b + 7500 \hspace{1.1em} \\[6pt]
    C - 7500 &= aN^b \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{the values of \(C - 7500\) versus \(N\)}}$
must entered into G.D.C.
    to determine John's equation using power regression method.
  - Calculating the values of $C-7500$, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/022157df-8846-4769-addf-993d91dcc3d0/images/1f7e6fa7-9fd5-4060-8aaa-a14e7aab59d1/99598c9925b5a9cd2c17f6f04553a8bf43f297df.svg)


    Entering the data above into G.D.C. as described in part (h)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.3em} C - 7500 &= 177N^{0.800} \hspace{2em} [\text{by power regression}]\\[6pt]
    C &= 177N^{0.800} + 7500\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we find
$\answer{a = 177}$
and
$\answer{b = 0.800}$
as expected.

title: Question 111
content: Sandra operates a pizzeria that has $24$ hours delivery service. Sandra thinks that the daily total production cost, $C$, in euros (EUR), and the number of pizzas made per day, $N$, can be related by the equation $$ C = aN^b + K, $$ where $a,b$ and $K$ are positive constants. Sandra estimates that the daily total fixed cost of $\text{operating}$ the $\text{pizzeria}$ is $1000$ EUR. - Write down the value of $K$. [1] After analysing the bookkeeping records of a particular working week, Sandra finds the data given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb0acab8-5dc0-4da0-b2ae-e9c280e0b35f/images/4e23917d-54ed-4b09-9333-7c0c9887c487/7bb8aad63a8010d3b18aca0ec2b8af0e9af7f108.svg) - Draw a scatter diagram of $\log_2(C-K)$ versus $\log_2 N$, scaling and shifting the axes if needed. [4] - State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your scatter diagram from part (b). [1] - Write down the equation of the regression line of $\log_2(C-K)$ on $\log_2 N$. [2] - Hence find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4] Sandra wants to increase the selling rate of pizzas up to $800$ items per day. - Using Sandra's equation, estimate the daily total cost of producing $800$ $\text{pizzas}$.[2] - State whether it is valid to use Sandra's equation to estimate the daily total cost of producing $800$ pizzas. Give a reason for your answer. [1] - - Describe how the data must be entered into your G.D.C. to determine Sandra's equation using power regression method. - Hence verify your answers to part (e). [4]
markScheme:
- $\answer{1000}$
- Calculating the values of $\log_2 N$ and $\log_2(C-1000)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb0acab8-5dc0-4da0-b2ae-e9c280e0b35f/images/a4a0598f-1773-4143-b4c0-43fa3acec483/6ed34dc57af21ba83ab1d7783038566a019696c0.svg)


  Hence, if we draw a scatter diagram of $\log_2(C-1000)$ versus
$\log_2 N$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb0acab8-5dc0-4da0-b2ae-e9c280e0b35f/images/ba1b960b-af66-4648-8cd3-21a512c38b91/ac6a60df9e23d37ccee604e1315d7e96fdca9f98.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- $\answer{\log_2(C-1000) = 0.853\log_2 N + 3.02}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Using the properties of logarithms, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.5em} \log_2(C-1000) &= 0.853\log_2 N + 3.02 \\[6pt]
  \log_2(C-1000) &= \log_2 N^{0.853} + \log_2 2^{3.02} \\[6pt]
  \log_2(C-1000) &= \log_2 (8.11N^{0.853}) \hspace{3em} [2^{3.02} \approx 8.11] \\[6pt]
  C - 1000 &= 8.11N^{0.853} \\[6pt]
  C &= 8.11N^{0.853} + 1000\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{a = 8.11}$
and  $\answer{b = 0.853}$
- Evaluating $C$ when $N = 800$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} C &= 8.11(800)^{0.853} + 1000 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 3430 \text{ EUR}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{Not valid, \(N = 800\) is not within the range of the given data}}$
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    C &= aN^b + 1000 \hspace{0.5em} \\[6pt]
    C - 1000 &= aN^b \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{the values of \(C - 1000\) versus \(N\)}}$
must entered into G.D.C.
    to determine Sandra's equation using power regression method.
  - Calculating the values of $C-1000$, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cb0acab8-5dc0-4da0-b2ae-e9c280e0b35f/images/84db4808-3293-4034-9822-257357cdc091/35ba533211e955abab6f16c3be55a978b4acd112.svg)


    Entering the data above into G.D.C. as described in part (h)
(i), we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10.1em} C - 1000 &= 7.56N^{0.866} \hspace{2em} [\text{by power regression}]\\[6pt]
    C &= 7.56N^{0.866} + 1000\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence we find
$\answer{a = 7.56}$
and
$\answer{b = 0.866}$
as expected.

title: Question 112
content: John is investigating a relationship between two sets of data, $X$ and $Y$. After creating a scatter plot with $\ln Y$ on the $y$-axis and $\ln X$ on the $x$-axis, John notices what appears to be a strong negative linear correlation. The line of best fit passes through the points $(1,3.6)$ and $(6,1.6)$, as shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ef7542bf-9af6-4711-830a-7d31be18c041/images/4453a3d6-68cd-41c3-9c57-b3b81ac9d601/ai1063.PNG) - Find an equation for $Y$ in terms of $X$.[4] John also has some data relating the same variable $Y$, with another variable $Z$. He thinks the data can be modelled by $\log_{10}Y = m\log_{10}Z + c$. Upon investigation, John does find a linear relationship between $\log_{10}Y$ and $\log_{10}Z$, with $m=0.6$ and $c=0.2$. - Find an equation for $X$ in terms of $Z$.[4]
markScheme:
- First, we form an equation of the form $\ln Y = m\ln X + c$, where $m$ is the gradient and $c$ is the $y$-intercept. For the gradient, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  m &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{1.6 - 3.6}{6 - 1} \\[8pt]
  m &= -0.4
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Using the formula for the equation of a straight line, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[8pt]
  \ln Y - 3.6 &= -0.4(\ln X - 1) \\[8pt]
  \ln Y &= -0.4\ln X + 4
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Now we make $Y$ the subject of the equation:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \ln Y &= \ln X^{-0.4} + 4 \hspace{3em}[a\ln b = \ln b^a]\\[8pt]
  Y &= e^{\ln X^{-0.4} + 4} \\[8pt]
  &= X^{-0.4} \cdot e^4 \hspace{3em}[a^{m+n} = a^m \cdot a^n] \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.7em}\tcbhighmath{Y = 54.6\,X^{-0.4}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- We have $\log_{10}Y = 0.6\log_{10}Z + 0.2$. Therefore,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \log_{10}Y &= \log_{10}Z^{0.6} + 0.2 \\[8pt]
  Y &= 10^{\log_{10}Z^{0.6} + 0.2} \\[8pt]
  Y &= 1.585\,Z^{0.6}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  From part (a) we have $Y = 54.6\,X^{-0.4}$. Hence, equating the right hand side of each equation,

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  1.585\,Z^{0.6} &= 54.6\,X^{-0.4} \\[8pt]
  1.585\,Z^{0.6} &= \dfrac{54.6}{X^{0.4}} \\[8pt]
  X^{0.4} &= \dfrac{54.6}{1.585\,Z^{0.6}} \\[8pt]
  &= 34.45\,Z^{-0.6} \\[8pt]
  \left(X^{0.4}\right)^{2.5} &= \left(34.45\,Z^{-0.6}\right)^{2.5} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.7em}\tcbhighmath{X = 6970\,Z^{-1.5}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

title: Question 113
content: This question is about several regression equations and differential equations that can be used to model the number of views of a popular video published by a celebrity. The following table shows the number of views $V$, in millions, of an internet celebrity has on her video channel $t$ hours after her last video was released. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f55c8eb-5664-4bcc-9237-78899795d3f9/images/501de319-17db-4078-88bd-375e001df7a0/1046a.PNG) The data is also shown on the following scatter diagram: ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f55c8eb-5664-4bcc-9237-78899795d3f9/images/8c5ffe2d-9c13-431f-8151-883d37edccf0/1046b.PNG) - - Find the equation of the regression line $V(t)$ on $t$. - Sketch the regression line on the scatter diagram above. - Find the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient, $r$. - Explain why it is not appropriate to conduct a hypothesis test on the value found in (a) (iii). [5] A proposed model for approximating the first few hours since the video was released is given by the differential equation $V'(t) = \beta V(t)$, where $\beta$ is a constant related to the impact of the videos published by the celebrity. - - Find the general solution to this differential equation. - Using the given data, write down the equation of the non-linear regression model suggested by part (b) (i). - Sketch this curve on the scatter diagram. - For this model, write down the value of $R^2$. - Comment on the suitability of this model. [9] A third model proposed is a logarithmic regression. - - Write down the equation of the logarithmic regression model. - Sketch this curve on the scatter diagram. - State one limitation of the logarithmic model in approximating the number of views in the first few hours after a video is released. [4] An estimate for $V'(t)$, $t\geq 3$, can be found using the formula $$ \begin{align*} V'(t) \approx \dfrac{V(t+3)-V(t-3)}{6} \end{align*} $$ The following table shows some estimates of $V'(t)$ according to the formula. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f55c8eb-5664-4bcc-9237-78899795d3f9/images/9e9d502d-32b4-422c-bfdf-23c7cc14c515/1046c.PNG) - Find the values of $p$ and $q$. Give your answer correct to one decimal place. [3] An improved model for $V$ capable of dealing with high values of $t$ is given by the differential equation $$ \begin{align*} \dfrac{V'(t)}{V(t)} = k - \dfrac{k}{L}V(t) \end{align*} $$ According to this model, the quotient $\dfrac{V'(t)}{V(t)}$ is a linear function of $V(t)$. - - Use linear regression to find the value of $L$ rounded to the nearest thousand. - Given that the solution to the differential equation is $V(t)=\dfrac{L}{1+Ce^{-kt}}$, where $k>0$, estimate the number of views the video will have over a long period of time. [7]

title: Question 1
content: In this question give all angles in radians. Let $z = 1 + 2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $w = 4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$. - Find $z+w$. [1] - Find: - $|z+w|$; - $\arg(z+w)$. [2] - Find $\theta$, the angle shown on the diagram below. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50c10ba6-2e1a-451a-9954-0ba12b6fac75/images/e3abd6a6-8ddf-4035-ba97-a07d91ca55c7/9f1b9b167af97e4b2c9ee84b7c9014f2cdaf63c7.svg)
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z+w &= (1+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) + (4 + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}) \\[6pt]
  &= (1+4) + (2+1){\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 5 + 3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The modulus of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    |z+w| &= \sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} \hspace{6.3em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 5.83}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The argument of $z+w$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \arg(z+w) &= \tan^{-1}(3/5) \hspace{7.25em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 0.540}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.7em} \theta &= \arg z - \arg (z+w) \\[6pt]
  &= \tan^{-1}(2/1) - \tan^{-1}(3/5) \\[6pt]
  &= (1.107148\dots) - (0.540419\dots) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.567}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 3
content: The complex numbers $z$ and $w$ correspond to the points A and B as shown on the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f49c4a4e-a8b9-40a0-9883-70b2dab8b609/images/f51352cb-3ef3-4ded-8d97-25718787a7a9/0c46fa70e78de8ef6fa11a8d28566cc1742d4a83.svg) - Find the exact value of $|z - w|$. [2] - - Find the exact perimeter of triangle AOB. - Find the exact area of triangle AOB. [4]
markScheme:
- Using the cosine rule, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} |z - w|^2 &= |z|^2 + |w|^2 - 2|z||w|\cos\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 5^2 + 5^2 - 2(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em} \bigg[\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\bigg] \\[10pt]
  |z - w|^2 &= 25(2-\sqrt{3}) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{|z - w| = \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}} \hspace{4.3em}
  $$

- 
  - The exact perimeter of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \text{perimeter} &= |z| + |w| + |z-w| \\[6pt]
    &= 5 + 5 + \textstyle 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \textstyle 10 + 5\sqrt{2-\sqrt{3}}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The exact area of triangle AOB is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} \text{area} &= \dfrac{1}{2}|z||w|\sin\left(\dfrac{\pi}{6}\right) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{1}{2}(5)(5)\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg[\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \dfrac{25}{4}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 4
content: Let $z_1 = 2\sqrt{3}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{7\pi}{12}\Big)$, $z_3 = 2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\theta$, and $z_2 = z_1 + z_3$ be represented by the points A, B and C on an Argand diagram as shown below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/0085c6d0-51f3-4387-8aec-3a391223c6f4/f4ed9162ce8f5fbe06e47de0f00519455d24ad0d.svg) The shape OABC is a rectangle. - Show that $\theta = \dfrac{\pi}{12}$. [1] - Find $\arg\hspace{0.05em}(z_1 - z_2)$. [1] - Express $z_2$ in modulus-argument form. [4]
markScheme:
- From the diagram, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \theta &= \arg z_1 - \text{A\^{O}C} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{7\pi}{12} - \dfrac{\pi}{2} = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\dfrac{\pi}{12}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we illustrate $z_1 - z_2$ on the same Argand diagram, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)


  Hence the argument of $z_1 - z_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \arg\hspace{0.05em}(z_1 - z_2) &= \text{C\^{O}D} - \arg z_3 \hspace{0.75em} \\[14pt]
  &= \pi - \dfrac{\pi}{12} \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{11\pi}{12}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4cd04149-8449-4105-9b22-5e42b343e164/images/04442292-e044-4715-9411-67fdf5174007/61b40c253f2d12de7c4ab40eafed5e3eb9ac59d0.svg)


- Using the right triangle OBC, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} |z_2|^2 &= |z_1|^2 + |z_3|^2 \\[6pt]
  |z_2|^2 &= (2\sqrt{3})^2 + 2^2 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
  |z_2|^2 &= 16 \\[7pt]
  |z_2| &= 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the right triangle OBC again, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \cos(\text{B\^{O}C}) &= \dfrac{|z_3|}{|z_2|} \\[6pt]
  \cos(\text{B\^{O}C}) &= \dfrac{2}{4} \hspace{3em} \left(=\dfrac{1}{2}\right) \\[9pt]
  \text{B\^{O}C} &= \dfrac{\pi}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \arg z_2 &= \arg z_3 + \text{B\^{O}C} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{12} + \dfrac{\pi}{3} \\[8pt]
  &= \dfrac{5\pi}{12}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we write $z_2$ in
modulus-argument form, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \answer{z_2 = 4\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{5\pi}{12}\Big)}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 6
content: Consider the complex number $z$, such that $z=2\hspace{0.05em}e^{\frac{\pi}{a}i}$, where $|a|>1, a \in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that $z$ can never be a positive real number. [2] Now consider the complex number $w$, such that $w=-\sqrt{2}+\sqrt{2}i$. There is one value of $a$ such that $\frac{z}{w}$ is a positive real number. - Find this value of $a$. [6]

title: Question 7
content:
On an Argand diagram, the complex numbers
$z_1 = 2 + 2\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$,
$z_2 = 1 - {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ and $z_3 = z_1z_2$ are
represented by the vertices of a triangle.
Find the area of the triangle.
markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{1.1em} |z_1| &= \textstyle \sqrt{2^2+(2\sqrt{3})^2} \\[6pt]
&= 4 \\[12pt]
|z_2| &= \sqrt{1^2+(-1)^2} \\[6pt]
&= \sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_1 &= \tan^{-1}(2\sqrt{3}/2) \\[6pt]
&= \ang{60} \\[12pt]
\arg z_2 &= \tan^{-1}(-1/1) \\[6pt]
&= -\ang{45}\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the property of modulus, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
|z_3| &= |z_1z_2| \\[6pt]
&= |z_1||z_2| \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
&= 4\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\arg z_3 &= \arg(z_1z_3) \\[6pt]
&= \arg z_1 + \arg z_2 \\[6pt]
&= \ang{15}\end{aligned}
$$

If we sketch the triangle whose vertices
represent $z_1$, $z_2$ and $z_3$ on an Argand diagram, we have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d9540a91-3a6d-402f-96f6-82e7e2baf51e/images/357aebcc-946f-48d1-9cb4-5216d45536d4/cce5162c3d61fa13f25a6e2323562142371b3997.svg)


Hence the area of the triangle ABC is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{area(A\^{B}C)} &= \text{area(A\^{O}C)} + \text{area(B\^{O}C)} - \text{area(A\^{O}B)} \\[8pt]
&= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{45} + \dfrac{1}{2}(\sqrt{2})(4\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{60} - \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(\sqrt{2})\sin \ang{105} \\[8pt]
&\answer{\approx 8.73}\end{aligned}
$$

title: Question 9
content: Consider two power sources with voltages $V_1$ and $V_2$ respectively, where $\omega$ is the frequency of the power source in Hertz (Hz) and $t$ is time in seconds. It is given that $$ \begin{align*} V_1 = 161\sin(\omega t + 1.047)\,. \end{align*} $$ When the two power sources are combined, the resultant voltage $V_1 + V_2$ is given by $$ \begin{align*} V_T = 240\sin(\omega t + 1.883)\,. \end{align*} $$ - Find $V_2$. Give your answer in the form $a\sin(\omega t + b)$, where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$.[6] - Hence, determine the difference in phase shift between $V_1$ and $V_2$.[2]

title: Question 11
content: Let $z = \sqrt{2}\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\left(\dfrac{3\pi}{8}\right)$ and $w = 2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\bigg(\dfrac{n\pi}{24}\bigg)$ , where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Find the value of $z^6$. Give your answer in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$, where $r \geq 0$, $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$. [2] - Find the value of $(wz)^4$ for $n = 5$. Give your answer in the form $re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\theta}$, where $r \geq 0$, $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$. [3] - Find the smallest integer $n > 9$ such that $\dfrac{z}{w} \in \mathbb{R}$. [3]
markScheme:
We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
z &= \sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}} \\[12pt]
w &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{n\pi}{24}} \hspace{1em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$


- Therefore

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  z^6 &= \left(\sqrt{2}\,e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}\right)^6 \\[12pt]
  &= 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{9\pi}{4}} \\[12pt]
  &= 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{9\pi}{4} - 2\pi\right)} \hspace{0.75em} [\text{so that $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$}] \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-0.9em}\answer{z^6 = 8e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{4}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (wz)^4 &= \Big[\big(2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{5\pi}{24}}\big)\hspace{-0.2em}\big(\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}\big)\Big]^{4} \hspace{3em} [\text{for $n=5$}] \\[12pt]
  &= \Big[2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{5\pi}{24} + \frac{3\pi}{8}\right)}\Big]^{4} \\[12pt]
  &= \big(2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{7\pi}{12}}\big)^{4} \\[12pt]
  &= 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{7\pi}{3}} \\[12pt]
  &= 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(\frac{7\pi}{3}- 2\pi)} \hspace{0.75em} [\text{so that $-\pi < \theta \leq \pi$}] \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.5em}\answer{(wz)^4 = 64e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The quotient $\dfrac{z}{w}$ is a real number when
$\arg\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{z}{w}\Big)$ is a multiple of $\pi$.
We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{z}{w} &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{8}}}{2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{n\pi}{24}}} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{3\pi}{8} - \frac{n\pi}{24}\right)} \\[12pt]
  &= \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(\frac{9-n}{24}\right)\pi} \\[12pt]
  \arg\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(\dfrac{z}{w}\Big) &= \left(\frac{9-n}{24}\right)\pi\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore the smallest integer $n > 9$ such that
$\dfrac{z}{w} \in \mathbb{R}$ is
$\answer{n = 33}$

title: Question 12
content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{2}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eecd4b7e-d849-40ed-986b-85883ff7b716/images/f2f17a3e-671d-4ce2-8659-1788668037b1/7e711daec273ec9c0f630b852aae229a5a09d558.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})\hspace{0.05em}z$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.5em} z^2 &= 2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{2\pi}{3}} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{2\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-1 + \sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}} \end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} z^3 &= 2\sqrt{2}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\pi} \\[9pt]
    &= 2\sqrt{2}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos \pi + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin \pi \Big] \\[9pt]
    &\answer{=-2\sqrt{2} + 0{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eecd4b7e-d849-40ed-986b-85883ff7b716/images/ded0ec5a-bcd5-4df9-ad7f-598af8270fb2/ee3e2d0e8670f88c39e4d0221f05849bcdba3ebd.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{3^2 + (-3)^2} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{18} \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sqrt{2}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[13pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[14pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[14pt]
  \hspace{3.1em} |(3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = (3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})z] \\[14pt]
  |3-3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}||z| &= 1 \\[12pt]
  3\sqrt{2}\hspace{0.05em}r &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}}{6}} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

title: Question 13
content: Let $z = re^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{6}}$ where $r \in \mathbb{R}^+$. - For $r = \sqrt{3}$, - express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in the form $a+b{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}$ where $a, b \in \mathbb{R}$; - draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram. [4] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8b7f053-da8d-4e58-93be-10882e6392eb/images/92508df3-14ba-4834-b3e9-4f2f3338ae54/633c15de281dbaeb852d4279b825abc3a94854e8.svg) - Given that the integer powers of $w = \dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}$ lie on a unit circle centred at the origin, find the value of $r$. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - If we express $z^2$ and $z^3$ in Cartesian form, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} z^2 &= 3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{3}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{3}\Big)\Big] \\[4pt]
    &\answer{=\dfrac{3}{2} + \dfrac{3\sqrt{3}}{2}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5.3em} z^3 &= 3\sqrt{3}e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{\pi}{2}} \\[10pt]
    &= 3\sqrt{3}\Big[\hspace{-0.1em}\cos\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big) + {\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\sin\Big(\frac{\pi}{2}\Big)\Big] \\[10pt]
    &\answer{=0+3\sqrt{3}{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we draw $z^2$ and $z^3$ on the following Argand diagram, we
have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f8b7f053-da8d-4e58-93be-10882e6392eb/images/269127e3-b920-40c3-9c56-96e0a5491f22/ecdfaa8e1f1031e684d45d25638e79596842fb1a.svg)



- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}| &= \sqrt{6^2 + 2^2} \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &= \sqrt{40} \\[6pt]
  &= 2\sqrt{10}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the properties of modulus,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  |w^k| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [\text{for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}$}]  \\[16pt]
  |w|^k &= 1 \\[17pt]
  |w| &= 1 \\[15pt]
  \hspace{3.9em} \Big|\dfrac{z}{6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}}\Big| &= 1 \hspace{3em} [w = z/(6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu})] \\[8pt]
  \dfrac{|z|}{|6+2{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}|} &= 1 \\[9pt]
  \dfrac{r}{2\sqrt{10}} &= 1 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{r = 2\sqrt{10}} \hspace{1.3em}
  $$

title: Question 14
content: Two voltage sources are connected to a circuit. At time $t$ milliseconds (ms), the voltage from the first source is $V_1(t) = 12\cos(20t)$ and the voltage from the second source is $V_2(t) = 18\cos(20t+5)$, where both $V_1(t)$ and $V_2(t)$ are measured in volts. - Write, in the form $V(t) = A\cos\hspace{0.05em}(\omega t+\varphi)$, an expression for the total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms. [4] - Hence write down the highest voltage in the circuit. [1]
markScheme:
- The total voltage in the circuit at time $t$ ms is given by
$V(t) = V_1(t) + V_2(t)$.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} V(t) &= 12\cos(20t) + 18\cos(20t+5) \\[7pt]
  &= \mathrm{Re}\big[12\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(20t) + 18\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}(20t+5)\big] \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Re}\big[12e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t} + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t+5)}\big]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  12e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t} + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t+5)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[12 + 18e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5}\big] \\[6pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[17.1 - 17.3{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}20t}\big[24.3e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.790}\big] \hspace{3.1em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[6pt]
  &\approx 24.3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t-0.790)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V(t) &\approx \mathrm{Re}\big[24.3e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(20t-0.790)}\big] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 24.3\hspace{0.05em}\cos(20t-0.790)} \hspace{3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Hence the highest voltage in the circuit is
$\answer{24.3\hspace{0.25em}\text{volts}}$

title: Question 15
content: The sunset time in Paris can be modelled by the function $$ \mathrm{S}(t) = 1.85\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52\hspace{0.05em}t - 1.57) + 19.5 $$ where $t$ is time in months, from the beginning of January. The sunrise time can similarly be modelled by $$ \mathrm{R}(t) = 1.35\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52\hspace{0.05em}t - 4.7) + 7.5 $$ Both $\mathrm{S}(t)$ and $\mathrm{R}(t)$ are measured in hours since midnight. $\mathrm{S}(t)$ can be expressed as $\mathrm{im}(z_1)+19.5$ and $\mathrm{R}(t)$ can be expressed as $\mathrm{im}(z_2)+7.5$, where $z_1,z_2 \in \mathbb{C}$. - Write down expressions for $z_1$ and $z_2$. Give your answers in the form $z_{1,2}=r\,e^{\theta i}$.[2] The number of daylight hours in Paris, $\mathrm{D}(t)$, is given by $\mathrm{D}(t)=\mathrm{S}(t)-\mathrm{R}(t)$. - Hence show that the number of hours of daylight in Paris can be modelled by the function $$ \mathrm{D}(t)=3.20\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.52t-1.57) + 12 $$ [6] - According to the model, find: - the highest number of hours of daylight in a year; - The approximate number of months per year in which there is at least 14 hours of daylight. [5]

title: Question 17
content: The revenues of a four seasons hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{R}(t) = 58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t - 1.25) + 204$, where $t$ is the number of days after midnight on $31$ December. In a similar way, the operating costs of the hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{C}(t) = 31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t + 1.14) + 85.0$. Both $\mathrm{R}(t)$ and $\mathrm{C}(t)$ are measured in thousand dollars. - Show that the profits of the hotel can be modelled by the function $\mathrm{P}(t) = 83.9\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.51) + 119$. [3] - According to the model, find: - the highest profit the hotel will make; - the date on which the highest profit will occur. [3]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{P}(t) &= \mathrm{R}(t) - \mathrm{C}(t) \\[9pt]
  &= (58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) + 204) - (31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14) + 85.0) \\[9pt]
  &= \big[58.2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) - 31.4\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14)\big] + (204 - 85.0) \\[9pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[58.2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.25) - 31.4\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t+1.14)\big] + 119 \\[8pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\big[58.2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.25)} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t+1.14)}\big] + 119\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  58.2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.25)} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t+1.14)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[58.2e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.25} - 31.4e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.14}\big] \\[8pt]
  [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{3em} &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[5.24-83.8{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \\[8pt]
  [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{3em} &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}0.0172t}\big[83.9e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}1.51}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 83.9e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.51)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{P}(t) &\approx \mathrm{Im}\big[83.9e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(0.0172t-1.51)}\big] + 119 \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 83.9\sin\hspace{0.05em}(0.0172t-1.51) + 119}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - According to the model, the highest profit is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{P_{max}} &\approx 83.9 + 119 \\[8pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$203 \text{ thousand}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we sketch the graph of $y = \mathrm{P}(t)$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a771343a-1612-47bb-9629-9a6f18d261c8/images/05fac9bf-641e-4d76-a847-d751b1246a59/543d375a9ce4d0222b972c2179c98d4a685548a5.svg)


    Hence the highest profit occurs on $\text{day } 179$ or
$\answer{\text{June } 28}$

title: Question 18
content: In an unbalanced three-phase electrical circuit, the current at time $t$ ms is given by $I(t) = 2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big)$, where $I(t)$ is measured in milliamperes (mA). - Write $I(t)$ in the form $A\cos\hspace{0.05em}(\omega t+\varphi)$. [4] - Hence find the highest current flowing through the circuit, and the time it first occurs. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I(t) &= 2\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\sin\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big) \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\Big[2\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{0.05em}(5t) + 5\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{3\pi}{4}\Big) + 10\mathop{\mathrm{cis}}\hspace{-0.1em}\Big(5t-\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\Big)\Big] \\[6pt]
  &= \mathrm{Im}\Big[2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} + 5e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{3\pi}{4}\right)} + 10e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right)}\Big] \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we further have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} + 5e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{3\pi}{4}\right)} + 10e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\left(5t-\frac{5\pi}{4}\right)} &= e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t}\big[2 + 5e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{3\pi}{4}} + 10e^{-{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\frac{5\pi}{4}}\big] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} \big[-8.61 + 3.54{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}\big] \hspace{1.6em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}5t} \big[9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}2.75}\big] \hspace{1.6em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(5t+2.75)} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the identity
$\sin \theta = \cos(\theta-\textstyle\frac{\pi}{2})$ with
$\theta = 5t+2.75$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.4em} I(t) &\approx \mathrm{Im}\big[9.30e^{{\mathrm{\hspace{0.05em}i}\mkern 1mu}(5t+2.75)}\big] \hspace{2em} [\text{by $(1)$ and $(2)$}] \\[8pt]
  &\approx 9.30\sin\hspace{0.05em}(5t+2.75) \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 9.30\cos\hspace{0.05em}(5t+1.18)} \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2.75 - \textstyle \frac{\pi}{2} \approx 1.18$}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = I(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b19fb021-405d-4f87-861f-57db50190a0c/images/826559f4-1052-4b95-9c53-4601db6b6fc2/edddcb5f4484a3ee01b2a7e1928a31daa1879cc9.svg)


  Hence the highest current is
$\answer{9.30\hspace{0.25em}\text{mA}}$
and the
$1$st time it $\text{occurs}$ is at  $\answer{1.02\hspace{0.25em}\text{ms}}$

title: Question 3
content: Hannah buys a car for $\$24\hspace{0.15em}900$. The value of the car depreciates by $16$ % each year. - Find the value of the car after $10$ years. [3] Patrick buys a car for $\$12\hspace{0.15em}000$. The car depreciates by a fixed amount each year, and after $6$ years it is worth $\$6200$. - Find the annual rate of depreciation of the car. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbf1c0c-9c5b-4ac3-9edf-a63b70a97e44/images/88e9f084-1c6e-4955-9bad-33565408c7dd/848a0a2395b69bf10b5ffc75fbbed6c738b8c64e.svg)


  Hence, using the compound depreciation formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 - \dfrac{r}{100}\bigg)^n \\[5pt]
  &= 24\hspace{0.25em}900\bigg(1 - \dfrac{16}{100}\bigg)^{10}  \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx \$4360}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6bbf1c0c-9c5b-4ac3-9edf-a63b70a97e44/images/afa47a69-1f95-43f7-9609-3fc3d093e416/80839ebacd99f943925e1048218639215d638a8d.svg)


  Hence, using the compound depreciation formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} 6200 &= 12\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 - \dfrac{r}{100}\bigg)^6  \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{7.7em} \answer{r \approx 10.4\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 7
content: On January the 1st 2017 Ji Sun had savings of $7,380. He decided to keep his money in a bank account that pays an annual interest rate of 4.7% per year which is compounded monthly. - Ji Sun left the money in the bank account until January the 1st 2025. Calculate the value of his investment on this day, giving your answer to 2 decimal places. [2] After 2 complete years of earning interest in the bank account, Ji Sun decided to move his money into a savings account which paid a higher rate of yearly interest, compounded monthly. - On January the 1st 2025 he is projected to have $11,747.40. Determine the annual interest rate of the savings account. [4]
markScheme:

  $$

  $$

  $$

  We solve this equation graphically

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}

title: Question 9
content: In this question give all answers correct to two decimal places. Charlie deposits $8000$ Canadian dollars (CAD) into a bank account. In $2$ years, the total amount in Oscar's account will be $\$8000$ CAD. - Find the amount that Oscar deposits in the bank account. [3]

  \mathrm{FV} - 2750\times20 &= 74\hspace{0.15em}062.88 - 55\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$19\hspace{0.15em}062.88} \end{aligned}
