title: Question 20
content: Greg has saved $2000$ British pounds (GBP) over the last six months. He decided to deposit his savings in a bank which offers a nominal annual interest rate of $\text{\(8\)\hspace{0.05em}\%}$, compounded monthly, for two years. - Calculate the total amount of interest Greg would earn over the two years. Give your answer correct to two decimal places. [3] Greg would earn the same amount of interest, compounded semi-annually, for two years if he deposits his savings in a second bank. - Calculate the nominal annual interest rate the second bank offers. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe610d27-a954-4e19-b5c0-7535e2b675b8/images/fcc1357b-4e66-4e93-8cbd-34948432cd76/d94b9efaa433da997063a9b0927befd8e7a68df2.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 2000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{8}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 2} \\[12pt]
  &= 2345.78 \text{ GBP}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total amount of interest earned is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} - \text{PV} &= 2345.78 - 2000 \hspace{2.2em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 345.78 \text{ GBP}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fe610d27-a954-4e19-b5c0-7535e2b675b8/images/4ba3785f-39ac-4776-83c7-b04c77097206/218c768ecef0bd0485a005a319e86a9adb263fd0.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.1em} 2345.78 &= 2000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100\times2}\bigg)^{2\times 2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.2em} \answer{r \approx 8.13\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 21
content: On January 1st 2023, Virgil deposits 1500 Canadian dollars (CAD) into a savings account which pays a nominal annual interest rate of $4.6\%$ compounded monthly. At the end of each month, Virgil deposits an extra CAD$\,1\,000$ into the savings account. After $k$ months, Virgil will have enough money to withdraw CAD$\,25\,000$. - Find the smallest possible value for $k$, given that $k$ is a whole number.[4] At this time, $k$ months, annual interest rates have improved. Virgil withdraws CAD$\,25\,000$ and re-invests the remaining money in the same account with the new nominal annual interest rate for 24 months, making no further deposits. After 24 months, Virgil has CAD$\,800$ in the account. - Determine the new nominal annual interest rate.[3]
markScheme:
- The following table summarizes the information we have been given, to be used in the financial solver on the G.D.C. Note that Present Value (PV) and Payment (PMT) should be negative, and Future Value (FV) should be positive:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000d745a-7168-4e23-9a92-1568e19ad9f2/images/a4115b9b-1c0f-4481-b2fb-a97b70f2d343/ai1057a.PNG)


  Note that, although the closest whole number to $22.42$ is $22$, at this time Virgil will have less than CAD$\,25\,000$. Hence it is only after $23$ months that Virgil can withdraw CAD$\,25\,000$.
  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The smallest possible value for $k$ is $23$.}}$
- Using our table from part (a), but adjusting N to 23, we find that when $k=23$, Virgil has CAD $\,25\,634.34$ available:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/000d745a-7168-4e23-9a92-1568e19ad9f2/images/c4802576-38dc-49f2-9463-c73a3490481f/ai1057b.PNG)


  Virgil is therefore re-investing CAD$\,634.34$ for 24 months, making no payments. At this time he has CAD $\,800$:

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The new nominal annual interest rate is approximately  $11.7\,\%$.}}$

title: Question 22
content: Melinda has $\$300\hspace{0.15em}000$ in a private foundation. Each year she donates $10\hspace{0.05em}\%$ of the money remaining in her private foundation to charity. - Find the maximum number of years Melinda can donate to charity while keeping at least $\$100\hspace{0.15em}000$ in the private foundation. [3] Bill invests $\$400\hspace{0.15em}000$ in a bank account that pays a nominal interest rate of $4$ %, compounded quarterly, for ten years. - Calculate the value of Bill's investment at the end of this time. Give your answer correct to the nearest dollar. [3]
markScheme:
- We can form an inequality using the compound interest formula, with a $\textcolor{red}{\text{minus}}$ sign instead of a plus sign, to show that Melinda's money is decreasing instead of increasing:

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{FV} &\leq \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 \textcolor{red}{-} \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} 
  \end{align*}
  $$

  We need to find the largest value $n$ so that the RHS is greater than or equal to the LHS. We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e854986-7c8c-4bbb-8249-3257b097b50e/images/d5dbbadb-073a-4390-9be7-0b924338a98a/ai109a.PNG)


  Hence we must solve the inequality

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  100\,000 &\leq 300\,000\bigg(1 - \dfrac{10}{100}\bigg)^{n} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{1}{3} &\leq 0.9^n
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Sketching the graphs of $y=\dfrac{1}{3}$ and $y=0.9^x$ and finding the point of intersection, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e854986-7c8c-4bbb-8249-3257b097b50e/images/dcc783a9-b923-433e-a2b4-3fdab031e4b6/ai109b.PNG)


  Hence we have $n \leq 10.427...$ and given that $n$ must be a whole number, the maximum number of years is $\answer{10}$
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0e854986-7c8c-4bbb-8249-3257b097b50e/images/684d5665-68cb-494e-a248-9c8c0a434421/d87692941dc43b1f610dcca79c498cfb3a932d8a.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{FV} &= \mathrm{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
  &= 400\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{4}{100\times4}\bigg)^{4\times10} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx \$595\hspace{0.15em}545} \end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 26
content: Julia wants to buy a house that requires a deposit of $74\hspace{0.15em}000$ Australian dollars (AUD). Julia is going to invest an amount of AUD in an account that pays a nominal annual interest rate of $5.5$ %, compounded monthly. - Find the amount of AUD Julia needs to invest to reach $74\hspace{0.15em}000$ AUD after $8$ years. Give your answer correct to the nearest dollar. [3] Julia's parents offer to add $5000$ AUD to her initial investment from part (a), however, only if she invests her money in a more reliable bank that pays a nominal annual interest rate only of $3.5$ %, compounded quarterly. - Find the number of years it would take Julia to save the $74\hspace{0.15em}000$ AUD if she accepts her parents money and follows their advice. Give your answer correct to the nearest year. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/520ffad3-690b-4fb3-890d-b50f4dc5c132/images/ac73771e-7dfd-45ca-ba48-14e31549496d/3787235f52ce0a9532d1fb499061fa26f27dacb9.svg)


  Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

  $$

title: Question 29
content: Bruce goes into a car dealership to purchase a new vehicle. The one he wants to buy costs $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$, however he doesn't have that much money in his bank. The salesman offers him a financing option of a $30$ % deposit followed by $12$ monthly payments of $\$1150$. - Find the amount of the deposit. [1] - Calculate the total cost of the loan under this financing option. [2] Bruce's father generously offers him an interest free loan of $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ to buy the car to avoid the expensive loan repayments. They agree that Bruce will repay the loan by paying his father $\$\hspace{0.05em}x$ in the first month and $\$\hspace{0.05em}y$ every following month until the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ is repaid. The total amount Bruce's father receives after $12$ months is $\$5200$. This can be expressed by the equation $x + 11y = 5200$. The total amount that Bruce's father receives after $24$ months is $\$10\hspace{0.15em}600$. - Write down a second equation involving $x$ and $y$. [1] - Determine the value of $x$ and the value of $y$. [2] - Calculate the number of months it will take Bruce's father to receive the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$. [3] Bruce decides to buy a cheaper car for $\$12\hspace{0.15em}000$ and invest the remaining $\$4000$. He is considering two investment options over four years. Option A: Compound interest at an annual rate of $6.5$ %. Option B: Compound interest at a nominal annual rate of $6$ %, compounded monthly. Express each answer in part (f) to the nearest dollar. - Calculate the value of each investment option after four years. - Option A. - Option B. [5]
markScheme:
- The amount of the deposit is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \mathrm{PV} &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000\times0.3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$4800}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The total cost of the loan is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4800 + 1150\times12 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$18\hspace{0.15em}600}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{x + 23y = 10\hspace{0.15em}600}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x+11y &= 5200 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  x + 23y &= 10\hspace{0.15em}600 \hspace{3em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system of linear equations $(1)$ and $(2)$, we
get

  $$
  
  \hspace{8.9em} \begin{array}{rl}
  &\answer{x = 250} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{y = 450}
  \end{array} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} 250 + 450n &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[8pt]
  n &= 35 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it will take Bruce's father
$\answer{36 \text{ months}}$
to receive the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$.
- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/83b5567c-360a-4827-bcf6-7981fa2e12e1/f5c80495cb4b6289d9e252ee117b474ac0267df8.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.1em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
    &= 4000\hspace{0.05em}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times 4}  \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5146}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/2a954c17-2361-4029-9e42-e5a49752668c/94b36ff454d13c51eba6ab9f5086d95bd5a04ffa.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 4} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5082}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 34
content: Lily and Eva both receive $50\hspace{0.15em}000$ Australian dollars (AUD) on their $18$th birthday. Lily deposits her $50\hspace{0.15em}000$ AUD into a bank account. The bank pays an annual interest rate of $5$ %, compounded yearly. Eva invests her $50\hspace{0.15em}000$ AUD into a high-yield mutual fund that returns a fixed amount of $3000$ AUD per year. - Calculate: - the amount in Lily's bank account at the end of the first year; - the total amount of Eva's funds at the end of the first year. [2] - Write down an expression for: - the amount in Lily's bank account at the end of the $n$th year; - the total amount of Eva's funds at the end of the $n$th year. [4] - Calculate the year in which the amount in Lily's bank account becomes greater than the amount in Eva's fund. [2] - Calculate: - the interest amount that Lily earns if invested for $12$ years, giving your answer correct to two decimal places; - the amount of funds that Eva earns for her investment if invested for $12$ years. [4]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cd45bbd6-5df5-41f8-b879-de3bf727d371/images/c9512c05-b8bf-433d-8dc0-f6aea96b77cb/328a5b6ca0a70c17db6ec544ec351e070664f88c.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[4pt]
    &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times 1} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 52\hspace{0.15em}500 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.8em} \mathrm{FV} &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000 + 3000\times1 \hspace{2em} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{= 53\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/cd45bbd6-5df5-41f8-b879-de3bf727d371/images/a7e6da9b-e991-4ce3-aa6c-8869aadd733a/b18073c0cd76ad6f2055e24c813e9a92346b6b01.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3em} \mathrm{FV} &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times n} \\[6pt]
    &= \hspace{0.525em}\answer{50\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.05em}(1 + 0.05)^n} \hspace{0.35em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \mathrm{FV} = \hspace{0.525em}\answer{50\hspace{0.15em}000 + 3000n} \hspace{0.9em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the inequality $(1) > (2)$ for $n$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.05em}(1 + 0.05)^n &> 50\hspace{0.15em}000 + 3000n \hspace{1.2em} \\[6pt]
  50\hspace{0.05em}(1 + 0.05)^n &> 50+3n \\[6pt]
  n &> 8.20\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence this will happen in
$\answer{9\text{th year}}$
- 
  - Substituting $n=12$ in the formula $(1)$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4em} \mathrm{FV} &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.05em}(1 + 0.05)^{12} \\[6pt]
    &= 89\hspace{0.15em}792.82 \text{ AUD}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the
amount of interest earned is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.4em} \mathrm{FV} - \text{PV} &= 89\hspace{0.15em}792.82 - 50\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 39\hspace{0.15em}792.82 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Substituting $n=12$ in the formula $(2)$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.9em} \mathrm{FV} &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000 + 3000(12) \\[6pt]
    &= 86\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ AUD}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the
amount of funds earned is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.1em} \mathrm{FV} - \text{PV} &= 86\hspace{0.15em}000 - 50\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 36\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 1
content: The diagram below shows a straight line $L_1$ which passes through A$(0,-2)$ and B$(8,0)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47b65cc9-515d-4eb0-ae20-be61fd47f030/images/e476ece8-ad04-4e3b-8740-1be6a35203d6/dd225af0bca38352f0853ac9a9eb9c1cd3829f36.svg) - Write down the coordinates of the midpoint of line segment [AB]. [2] Another line, $L_2$ , intersects the $y$-axis at C$(0,3)$ and is parallel to $L_1$. - Find the gradient of $L_2$. [2] - Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form $y = mx+c$. [2]
markScheme:
- $\answer{(4,-1)}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{12.2em} m_{L_2} &= m_{L_1}  \hspace{3em} [\text{since } L_2 \parallel L_1] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{0-(-2)}{8-0} \hspace{3em} [\text{by gradient formula}] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 0.25}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with C$(0,3)$ and $m = 0.25$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - 3 &= 0.25\hspace{0.05em}(x-0) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.3em} \answer{y = 0.25x + 3}
  $$

title: Question 2
content: A small town is planning the construction of a new road. The new road will pass through the point A$(0,5)$ and will be perpendicular to the road connecting the points B$(3,0)$ and C$(6,6)$. This information is shown in the following diagram. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b30beb64-0ecd-4246-8108-6275a6e4a3b6/images/8ae74cd9-ad4b-4f19-bde8-a50bf3a19b39/55d55a043dfcb136022e8a71a28efdbe577c0832.svg) - Find the gradient of the line through points B and C. [2] - Hence, state the gradient of the line through points A and D. [1] - Find the equation of the line through A and D. Give your answer in the form $y=mx+c$.[2] - Point D lies on the $x$-axis. Find the coordinates of point D.[2]
markScheme:
- Using the gradient formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{BC}} &= \dfrac{6-0}{6-3} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.2em}\tcbhighmath{m_{\mathrm{BC}} = 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since A and D lie on a perpendicular line to the line through B and
C we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AD}} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{\mathrm{BC}}} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-2.25em}\tcbhighmath{ m_{\mathrm{AD}} = -\dfrac{1}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The $y$-intercept of the line through points A and D is $(0,5)$, therefore we have $c = 5$. Using the gradient-intercept formula with $c = 5$ and $m=-\dfrac{1}{2}$, we get
$m=-\dfrac{1}{2}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{y = -\dfrac{1}{2}x + 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

- As point D lies on the $x$-axis, it has a $y$-coordinate of $0$. Using the solution from part (c)  and substituting in $y = 0$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0 &= -\dfrac{1}{2}x + 5 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2}x &= 5 \\[12pt]
  x &= 10\end{aligned}
  $$

  Therefore, point D has coordinates
$\answer{(10,0)}$

title: Question 4
content: The straight line, $L_1$, has the equation $y = \dfrac{1}{3}x-5$. - Write down the $y$-intercept of $L_1$. [1] - Write down the gradient of $L_1$. [1] The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through the point A$(2,4)$. - Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1] - Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a,b,d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]

- $\answer{m_{L_1} = 1/3}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

title: Question 5
content: The equation of a line $L_1$ is $y = 0.5x + p$. The point A$(2,-1)$ lies on $L_1$. - Find the value of $p$. [2] A second line, $L_2$ , is perpendicular to $L_1$ and intersects $L_1$ at point A. - Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1] - Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form $y = mx+c$. [2] - Write your answer to part (c) in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$.[1]
markScheme:
- Substituting $x = 2$ and $y = -1$ in the equation of $L_1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.2em}  -1 = 0.5(2) + p \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{p = -2}
  $$

- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.8em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since }L_2 \perp L_1] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{0.5} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= -2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with A$(2,-1)$ and $m = -2$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  y - (-1) &= -2\hspace{0.05em}(x-2) \hspace{0.25em} \\

  $$
  \hspace{2.2em} \answer{y = -2x + 3}

title: Question 6
content: The equation of a line $L_1$ is $y - 3x + 5 = 0$. - For the line $L_1$, find: - the $x$-intercept; - the gradient. [2] A second line, $L_2$, intersects the $y$-axis at P$(0,2)$ and is parallel to $L_1$. - Find the equation of $L_2$. Give your answer in the form $y = mx+c$. [1] A third line, $L_3$, passes through the point Q$(3,1)$ and is perpendicular to $L_1$. - Find the gradient of the line $L_3$. [1] - Find the equation of $L_3$, giving your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Substituting $y = 0$ in the equation of $L_1$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    0 - 3x + 5 &= 0 \hspace{2.3em} \\[9pt]
    5 &= 3x \\[4pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{3}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the point
$\answer{\text{A}(5/3,0)}$
is the $x$-intercept of $L_1$.
  - If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    y - 3x + 5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    y &= 3x - 5 \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = 3}$

- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.9em} m_{L_2} &= m_{L_1} \hspace{3em} [\text{since }L_2 \parallel L_1] \\[6pt]
  &= 3\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
P$(0,2)$ and $m = 3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.6em} \\[6pt]
  y - 2 &= 3\hspace{0.05em}(x-0) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = 3x + 2} \hspace{0.1em}
  $$

- The gradient of $L_3$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.2em} m_{L_3} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since }L_3 \perp L_1] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -\dfrac{1}{3}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with Q$(3,1)$ and $m = -1/3$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  y - 1 &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\hspace{0.05em}(x-3) \\[8pt]
  3y - 3 &= -x + 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x + 3y - 6 = 0} \hspace{6.5em}
  $$

title: Question 7
content: The coordinates of point K are $(-2,-3)$ and the coordinates of point N are $(8,6)$. M is the midpoint of [KN]. - Find the coordinates of M. [2] $L_1$ is the line which passes through K and N. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2] A new line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - - Write down the gradient of $L_2$. - Write down the equation of $L_2$ in the form $y = mx + c$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the coordinates of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-2 + 8} 2, \dfrac {-3 + 6} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(3, \dfrac 3 2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the gradient formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &=  \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {6 - (-3)}{8 - (-2)}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \dfrac {9} {10}}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_2} & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
    &\answer{  = -\dfrac {10}{9}}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - From (c) (i) we have $y = -\dfrac {10}{9} \,x + c$. To find $c$
we substitute the coordinates of M into the equation (since
$L_2$ passes through M).

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10} {9} \left(3 \right) + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
    \dfrac 3 2  & = -\dfrac {10}{3} + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac 3 2 + \dfrac {10} {3}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c & = \dfrac {29}{6}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of $L_2$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{ y = -\dfrac {10} {9}\, x + \dfrac {29}{6}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 8
content: The coordinates of point P are $(-4,6)$ and the coordinates of point Q are $(5,1)$. M is the midpoint of [PQ]. - Find the coordinates of M. [2] $L_1$ is the line which passes through P and Q. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [2] A new line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - - Write down the gradient of $L_2$. - Write down the equation of $L_2$ in the form $y = mx + c$. [3]
markScheme:
- Using the coordinates of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-4+5} 2, \dfrac {6+1} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(\dfrac 1 2, \dfrac 7 2\right)}\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}    \end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the gradient formula, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{0mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {1 - 6}{5-(-4)} \rule[-4mm]{0pt}{10mm}\\
  &\answer{  = -\dfrac 5 9}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}\\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
    &\answer{  = \dfrac 9 5}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - From (c) (i) we have $y = \dfrac 9 5 \,x + c$. To find $c$ we
substitute the coordinates of M into the equation (since $L_2$
passes through M).

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac 7 2  & = \dfrac 9 5 \left(\dfrac 1 2 \right) + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    \dfrac 7 2  & = \dfrac {9}{10} + c\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c       & = \dfrac 7 2 - \dfrac 9 {10}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    c       & = \dfrac {13}{5}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
    \end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of $L_2$ is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{ y = \dfrac 9 5\, x + \dfrac {13}{5}}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 9
content: The equation of a line $L_1$ is $2x + 3y = -5$. - Find the gradient of $L_1$. [1] A second line, $L_2$, is perpendicular to $L_1$. - Find the gradient of $L_2$. [1] The point P$(4,0)$ lies on $L_2$. - Find the equation of $L_2$, giving your answer in the form $ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [2] The point Q is the intersection of $L_1$ and $L_2$. - Find the coordinates of Q. [2]
markScheme:
- If we rewrite the equation of $L_1$ in the form $y = mx + c$, we
have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2x + 3y &= -5 \\[12pt]
  3y &= -2x - 5 \\[6pt]
  y &= -\dfrac{2}{3}x-\dfrac{5}{3} \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the gradient of $L_1$ is
$\answer{m_{L_1} = -2/3}$
- The gradient of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9em} m_{L_2} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L_1}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since }L_2 \perp L_1] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{(-2/3)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{3}{2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the point-gradient formula with P$(4,0)$ and $m = 3/2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 0 &= \dfrac{3}{2}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 4) \\[6pt]
  2y &= 3x - 12 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{3.45em} \answer{0 = 3x - 2y - 12}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L_1&:\hspace{1.0em} 2x + 3y = -5 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  L_2&:\hspace{1.0em} 3x - 2y = 12 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $x$ and $y$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{10.8em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  x &=& 2 \\[6pt]
  y &=& -3
  \end{array} \hspace{4em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of Q are
$\answer{(2,-3)}$

title: Question 10
content: The coordinates of point A are $(-1,-7)$ and the coordinates of point $B$ are $(5,2)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B. - Find the equation of $L_1$. [3] Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - Find the equation of $L_2$. [3]
markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {2 - (-7)}{5 - (-1)} \rule[-3.7mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{9}{6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  & = \dfrac 3 2 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{4.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = \dfrac 3 2 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute in the coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2   & = \dfrac 3 2 \,(5) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac {11} 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = \dfrac 3 2 \,x - \dfrac {11} 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 2 3 \end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have
$y = -\dfrac 2 3\, x + c$.
  Let's find coordinates of M. Using the coordinates of a midpoint
formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {-1 + 5} 2, \dfrac {-7 + 2} 2\right)\rule[-4mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -\dfrac 5 2\right)}\rule[0mm]{0pt}{6mm}  \end{aligned}
  $$

  To find $c$ we can substitute M into the equation (since $L_2$
passes through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -\dfrac 5 2 & = -\dfrac 2 3  (2) + c\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 5 2 + \dfrac 4 3\rule[-3mm]{0pt}{8mm}\\
  c   & = -\dfrac 7 6\rule[0mm]{0pt}{5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the
equation of $L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = -\dfrac 2 3  x - \dfrac 7 6}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 11
content: The coordinates of point A are $(6,-3)$ and the coordinates of point B are $(-2,-1)$. $L_1$ is the line which passes through A and B. - Find the equation of $L_1$. [3] Point M is the midpoint of [AB]. The line $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$ and passes through M. - Find the equation of $L_2$. [3]
markScheme:
- First, let's find the gradient of $L_1$. Using the gradient formula,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_1} &= \dfrac {y_2 - y_1} {x_2 - x_1}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \dfrac {-1 - (-3)}{-2 - 6} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &  = \dfrac{2}{-8} \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  & = -\dfrac 1 4 \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far the
equation of $L_1$ is $y = -\dfrac 1 4 \, x + c$. To find $c$ we can
substitute coordinates of B into the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -1  & = -\dfrac 1 4 (-2) + c\\[6pt]
  c   & = -\dfrac 3 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L_1$
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y    = -\dfrac 1 4 \,x - \dfrac 3 2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since $L_2$ is perpendicular to $L_1$, then

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{L_2}     & = -\dfrac 1 {m_{L_1}}\hspace{5mm}\\[6pt]
  & = 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  So far we have $y = 4 x + c$.
  Let's find the coordinates of the midpoint, M. Using the coordinates
of a midpoint formula, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text M &= \left(\dfrac {x_1+x_2} 2, \dfrac {y_1 + y_2} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  & = \left(\dfrac {6 - 2} 2, \dfrac {-3 - 1} 2\right)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\answer{  = \left(2, -2\right)}   \rule[0mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  To find $c$ we substitute M into the equation (since $L_2$ passes
through M).

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2  & = 4  (2) + c\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{3mm}\\
  c   & = -2 - 8\rule[-1.5mm]{0pt}{5.5mm}\\
  c   & = -10\rule[0mm]{0pt}{4mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of
$L_2$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &\answer{ y = 4 x - 10}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 13
content: Bruce goes into a car dealership to purchase a new vehicle. The one he wants to buy costs $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$, however he doesn't have that much money in his bank. The salesman offers him a financing option of a $30$ % deposit followed by $12$ monthly payments of $\$1150$. - Find the amount of the deposit. [1] - Calculate the total cost of the loan under this financing option. [2] Bruce's father generously offers him an interest free loan of $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ to buy the car to avoid the expensive loan repayments. They agree that Bruce will repay the loan by paying his father $\$\hspace{0.05em}x$ in the first month and $\$\hspace{0.05em}y$ every following month until the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$ is repaid. The total amount Bruce's father receives after $12$ months is $\$5200$. This can be expressed by the equation $x + 11y = 5200$. The total amount that Bruce's father receives after $24$ months is $\$10\hspace{0.15em}600$. - Write down a second equation involving $x$ and $y$. [1] - Determine the value of $x$ and the value of $y$. [2] - Calculate the number of months it will take Bruce's father to receive the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$. [3] Bruce decides to buy a cheaper car for $\$12\hspace{0.15em}000$ and invest the remaining $\$4000$. He is considering two investment options over four years. Option A: Compound interest at an annual rate of $6.5$ %. Option B: Compound interest at a nominal annual rate of $6$ %, compounded monthly. Express each answer in part (f) to the nearest dollar. - Calculate the value of each investment option after four years. - Option A. - Option B. [5]
markScheme:
- The amount of the deposit is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.4em} \mathrm{PV} &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000\times0.3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$4800}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The total cost of the loan is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4800 + 1150\times12 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \$18\hspace{0.15em}600}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{x + 23y = 10\hspace{0.15em}600}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x+11y &= 5200 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  x + 23y &= 10\hspace{0.15em}600 \hspace{3em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system of linear equations $(1)$ and $(2)$, we
get

  $$
  
  \hspace{8.9em} \begin{array}{rl}
  &\answer{x = 250} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{y = 450}
  \end{array} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.4em} 250 + 450n &= 16\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[8pt]
  n &= 35 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it will take Bruce's father
$\answer{36 \text{ months}}$
to receive the $\$16\hspace{0.15em}000$.
- 
  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/83b5567c-360a-4827-bcf6-7981fa2e12e1/f5c80495cb4b6289d9e252ee117b474ac0267df8.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.1em} \mathrm{FV} &= \text{PV}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{r}{100k}\bigg)^{kn} \\[5pt]
    &= 4000\hspace{0.05em}\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6.5}{100\times1}\bigg)^{1\times 4}  \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5146}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - We have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/109f5bcf-7e24-48da-933e-bf9abe847c29/images/2a954c17-2361-4029-9e42-e5a49752668c/94b36ff454d13c51eba6ab9f5086d95bd5a04ffa.svg)


    Hence, using the compound interest formula, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{5em} \mathrm{FV} &= 4000\bigg(1 + \dfrac{6}{100\times12}\bigg)^{12\times 4} \\[12pt]
    &\answer{\approx \$5082}\end{aligned}
    $$

title: Question 2
content: There are $225$ senior students studying Computer Science and $169$ senior students studying Mathematics at a university. According to an academic survey, $20$ % of these $\text{students}$ tell they will pursue a postgraduate degree, $8$ % will start a business, $52$ % will get employed, $15$ % will start freelancing and the remaining students will become $\text{research}$ assistants. The column matrix ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/362bbc2e-c246-4cbd-8513-5f628829a15c/images/7ec94812-b2c0-4cd6-88f9-64fa3447a6fe/5caf9380b8b050f42e1a579be00c4669ebfa829c.svg) represents the number of senior students studying Computer Science and Mathematics. - Write down a row matrix, $\bm{R}$, to represent the percentages, in decimal form, of senior students who will choose one of the five routes after graduation. markScheme:

title: Question 5
content: The Brown, Miller and Taylor families pay utility bills for their houses each month. The table below shows the amount of electricity, water and gas consumed during January by each family, and the total cost of the utilities. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/0ed8b5d3-0b26-4aaa-9363-4388163154b1/4c79f485c80ba0239ecc4cfcc637b51df6e48bea.svg) Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the prices, in dollars, for $1$ kWh of electricity, $1$ m$^3$ of water and $1$ m$^3$ of gas, respectively. - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represents the information in the table above. [2] - Using matrices, find the price for each of the utility. [2] The Smith family also pay utility bills each month. The table below shows the amount of electricity, water and gas consumed during January by the Smith family. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/ddce5317-71bc-4d06-bd45-53079b3092f5/00ca88f1397a994795e3b84ae8c62e66b719b0b0.svg) - Calculate the total cost of the utilities for the Smiths. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
  950x &+& 72y &+& 448z &=& 343.59 \\[3pt]
  788x &+& 88y &+& 356z &=& 314.68 \\[3pt]
  532x &+& 49y &+& 298z &=& 219.43
  \end{array}} \qref{(1)} \hspace{0.6em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/271993c3-62c6-4385-9f6a-69adee2c3fcd/30358a75db00011708b84ec520ef55df879b2a52.svg)


  Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bcc63680-86b3-473a-b161-293755d5dff2/images/e9419910-5963-43c3-ae96-10010f32e1ea/d50fe173dd0736bf21c2972d4d6e6feec7a7d478.svg)


  Hence the prices for the utilities are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Electricity} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{10.5 \text{ cents per kWh}} \\[6pt]
  \text{Water} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{1.24 \text{ dollars per }m^3} \\[6pt]
  \text{Gas} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{34.5 \text{ cents per }m^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The total cost of the utilities for the Smiths is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1124\times0.105 + 115\times1.24 + 598\times0.345 &= \$466.93 \approx \hspace{0.525em}\answer{\$467}\end{aligned}
  $$

Justify your answer. [2]

content: Austin allocates a portion of his employment salary each month to investing and invests this money into two stock funds: A and B. [2] - Interpret the meaning of the elements with values - $0.1$ - $0.7$ [2] The initial state of his investment portfolio is $100\%$ in stock fund B. - - Find the investment proportion in stock fund A after $3$ months. - Determine the long term steady state proportion of his investment between the two stock funds. [4]
markScheme:
- The given diagram can be described using the table below.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8318a37b-12b9-47f6-bffa-d16786b4d2b4/images/d6d33234-8f33-46aa-9446-41b8d28be120/d542444328236b9efce08a35ffec714b86e3ed6a.svg)


  Hence the transition matrix is

-

-

    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8318a37b-12b9-47f6-bffa-d16786b4d2b4/images/e7c8c830-9a58-414a-ad1c-ad57a88efa7b/0e99c3229e0a2e62055586e70663c42603e754e0.svg)


    $\answer{\text{The investment proportion in stock A after \(3\) months will be \(58.8\%\)}}$.
  - Let
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8318a37b-12b9-47f6-bffa-d16786b4d2b4/images/d61f65b3-fb60-4c5d-8b85-7e1136fa82a4/dbbe440f892490c3649e3046d5c732b6d2b45ec4.svg)

    This gives us the system of equations:

    $$
    \left \{ \begin{aligned}
    0.9a + 0.3b &= a \\
    0.1a + 0.7b &= b
    \end{aligned} \right.
    $$


    $$
    \left \{\begin{aligned}
    -0.1a + 0.3b &= 0 \\[3pt]
    0.1a - 0.3b &= 0 \phantom{\hspace{0.9em}}

    b &= 0.25 \\[3pt]
    a &= 0.75
    \end{aligned}

    Therefore, the long term steady state
proportions between the two stock funds is

    \text{Stock fund A} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{0.75} \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]

title: Question 12
content: When a ball is thrown from the top of a tall building, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c\,,$ where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres. After $1$ second, the ball is $84.3$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $93.9$ m; after $8$ seconds, $42.3$ m. - - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Use matrices to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3] - Find the height of the building. [1] - Find the time it takes for the ball to hit the ground. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    
    \answer{\begin{array}{rcccccl}
    a &+& b &+& c &=& 84.3 \\[3pt]
    4a &+& 2b &+& c &=& 93.9 \\[3pt]
    64a &+& 8b &+& c &=& 42.3
    \end{array}} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we express the system of linear equations $(1)$ as a matrix
equation, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa6bc1e0-527f-4b17-bf69-2b0fc42d8867/images/865960d0-98ce-4b87-a675-6a46a2ee65ce/b40b58be9e04029307e50815631013b0e434f45c.svg)


    Hence, if we solve the matrix equation $(2)$, we get
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fa6bc1e0-527f-4b17-bf69-2b0fc42d8867/images/1b3b62dd-72c9-42d4-8867-f02c938bd983/04caede963f7db2aac1bc0812ea44cf5b6a29875.svg)


    Hence we find
$\answer{a = -2.6, \hspace{0.25em} b = 17.4, \hspace{0.25em} c = 69.5}$

- Evaluating $s(t)$ at $t = 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.2em} s(0) &= -2.6(0)^2 + 17.4(0) + 69.5 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 69.5 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $s(t) = 0$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2.6t^2 + 17.4t + 69.5 &= 0 \hspace{10.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.6em} \answer{t \approx 9.50 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 13
content: The vegetables sold at supermarkets in a town are supplied by three major retail suppliers: A, B and C. According to an analysis report, supplier A retains $80$ % of their customers each year and lose $15$ % to supplier B and $5$ % to supplier C. Meanwhile, supplier B retains $70$ % of their customers each year and lose $20$ % to supplier A and $10$ % to supplier C. Supplier C retains $75$ % of their customers each year and lose $10$ % to supplier A and $15$ % to supplier B. The report also shows that suppliers A, B and C currently hold a market share of $50$ %, $25$ % and $25$ %, respectively. - Find the market share held by each supplier after three years.   Thus, the market share held by each supplier after three years is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Supplier A} &:\hspace{0.75em} \hspace{0.525em}\answer{0.454} \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]

- Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ be the market shares held by suppliers A, B and

title: Question 14
content: Laura creates a list of her favorite songs that includes three genres: Jazz, Slow Rock and Country. After her current song ends she randomly selects the next song and the probabilities of genre of the next song are outlined in the following table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af9295d1-85bf-4a88-b559-5ec47c2066cd/images/daa05bb6-a0e7-48b6-8dab-6e6d47862521/3f8039b268704a957cd1f3549fbc55eddf494e05.svg) Laura starts her day with a Slow Rock song and is now listening to her fourth song. - Determine the genre of music she is currently most likely listening to. [3] - Determine which genre of music she listens to most over the long term. [2]
markScheme:
- We have the transition matrix $\bm{T}$ and the initial state as
follows.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af9295d1-85bf-4a88-b559-5ec47c2066cd/images/9423dc53-6d93-41d4-8625-78ecaeb70345/d414430718958e8fee8eadf7c4a88427e1957a1c.svg)


  If the first song is the initial state,
$\bm{s_0}$, then the probabilities of the genre of song 4 can be
found by
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af9295d1-85bf-4a88-b559-5ec47c2066cd/images/cbd484f3-bb92-4a90-97dc-81c4bb65bc70/a93fb725c0cc70666b003e464dcc775d83cbd8ad.svg)


  $\answer{\text{Hence, the genre Laura is most likely listening to is Slow Rock.}}$
- Solving matrix equation $\bm{Ts} = \bm{s}$, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/af9295d1-85bf-4a88-b559-5ec47c2066cd/images/25e15a7a-4bba-4e47-b051-cfc7fd5441fc/f602e33493e695a752661b7547747c04609bc2e4.svg)


  The third equation can be ignored as it is the sum of the first two
equations and therefore redundant. We can replace it with
$a + b + c = 1$ as the probabilities must sum to $1$. Hence we get

  $$
  \left \{ \begin{aligned}
  -0.4a + 0.2b +0.3c &= 0 \\[3pt]
  0.2a - 0.5b + 0.4c &= 0 \\[3pt]
  \phantom{0.0}a + \phantom{0.0}b + \phantom{0.0}c &= 1
  \end{aligned} \right.
  $$

  Using GDC to solve this system of linear equations, we get

title: Question 16
content: A discrete dynamical system is described by the following transition matrix, $\bm{T}$, ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/90205c80-20d6-4cc5-a063-71306cf58ee8/cf10a27b504c9599c9adc42101e9bc3c0f6527ac.svg) The state of the system is defined by the proportions of population with a particular characteristic. - Use the characteristic polynomial of $\bm{T}$ to find its eigenvalues. [2] - Find the corresponding eigenvectors of $\bm{T}$. [2] - Hence find the steady state matrix $\bm{s}$ of the system. [2]
markScheme:
- The characteristic polynomial of $\bm{T}$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \mathrm{det}(\bm{T} - \lambda \bm{I}) &= 
  \begin{vmatrix}[cc] \hspace{0.05em} 0.3 - \lambda & 0.8 \\ 0.7 & 0.2 - \lambda \hspace{0.25em} \end{vmatrix} \\[4pt] 
  &= (0.3 - \lambda)(0.2 - \lambda) - 0.7 \cdot 0.8\\[3pt]
  &= \lambda^2 - 0.5\lambda - 0.5
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving the
characteristic equation $\mathrm{det}(\bm{T} - \lambda \bm{I}) = 0$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \lambda^2 - 0.5\lambda - 0.5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-2.15cm}\answer{\lambda_1 = -0.5,\,\lambda_2 = 1} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- Let $\bm{X}_1$ and $\bm{X}_2$ be the corresponding eigenvectors.
For $\lambda_1 = -0.5$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/caa9ebcf-f4f9-43a9-8d27-c455a6091293/7df9d643ed882d2a29eb4453e220c9073fd952ba.svg)


  Hence we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/54ea16af-01a3-49ed-a211-ca60c1af55d8/3da39a5a20086f595d92c990ff12f04e09793b30.svg)


  For $\lambda_2 = 1$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/a158dd50-d25b-4ba8-b8e1-6750cd489040/1b7a31cb4a6e37de055dac6ac90697cca6c3e440.svg)


  Hence we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/ece051fd-58f8-436a-8e11-a069052b70b3/03a68747a6cdf12d79fc22f2512ff82386b331dd.svg)


- A steady state $\bm{s}$ must satisfy the equation
$\bm{Ts} = \bm{s}$. This is equivalent to an eigenvector for
$\lambda = 1$. In addition, since the steady state represents the
proportions of population, its elements must sum up to $1$. Hence we
get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39fd5db8-a6fd-4077-9ba7-ea86a389a9ac/images/aeafb3e7-9b0a-4fc5-81da-1c4f751cc76f/f5e7cc65f9b9a10f812cf8aa34611b87a3af41fd.svg)

title: Question 19
content: Steve watches a TV show that has a small section dedicated to trivia quiz questions, where a randomly selected person from the audience is asked to answer 5 general knowledge questions in a row. The following table records the number of correct answers Steve obtains from watching 100 episodes of the program. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/762ccace-a1e8-48e6-bedd-4b404b983137/images/01dfd6f2-abbd-4254-8b78-d06b65b60b27/ai1044a.PNG) - Find Steve's mean number of correct answers per show. [2] Steve suspects that his number of correct answers can be modelled by a binomial distribution with $n=5$, and decides to carry out a $\chi^2$ goodness of fit test. - Using the data from the table, find the estimated value of $p$ for the binomial model.[1] - - Use the binomial model to find the probability that Steve gets all 5 questions incorrect. Express your answer to two significant figures. - Find the expected frequency for zero correct answers.[3] As some expected frequencies are less than $5$, Steve combines two rows in the table to obtain the following updated table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/762ccace-a1e8-48e6-bedd-4b404b983137/images/2df69f12-69ee-4723-8a02-25e4fa044ef5/ai1044b.PNG) - Steve uses this table to carry out a $\chi^2$ goodness of fit test to test the hypothesis that the data follow a binomial distribution with $n=5$ at the $10\%$ significance level. For this test, state: - the null hypothesis; - the number of degrees of freedom; - the $p$ value; - the conclusion, justifying your answer.[6] - Using the binomial model, find the probability that during the next show, Steve answers all five questions correctly.[2] Steve's friend Tony considers it might be better to model the problem by using states, where R means a correct answer, and W is an incorrect answer. To simplify the model, Tony proposes a transition of only two states with frequencies shown in the following table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/762ccace-a1e8-48e6-bedd-4b404b983137/images/faadc919-547c-4c77-8ee8-5e8be8f8bcc7/ai1044c.PNG) - - Find the probability, in the form $\dfrac{p}{q}$, that Steve gets a question incorrect given that he correctly answered the previous question. - Write down the transition matrix, $\bm{T}$, for this model.[3] - - Show that the characteristic polynomial for the transition matrix can be expressed as $39\lambda^2-47\lambda + 8 = 0$. - Hence, or otherwise, find the eigenvalues of $\bm{T}$. - Find the eigenvectors of $\bm{T}$.[7] Steve is leaving his home country for a working vacation and won't see the show for at least 6 months. When he returns, he will watch the first episode of the show and attempt to get all five questions correct. Tony claims that, according to the transition model, the probability of this occurring is approximately 10%. - Determine whether Tony's claim is correct.[4]

title: Question 20
content: A water park lends life jackets to its visitors. The park has two stations, $A$ and $B$, where clients can take a life jacket and they can return the life jacket to either of the two stations. It is found that at the end of a day, $81$% of the life jackets are returned to the same station they were taken from, while the other $19$% are returned to the other station. - Write down a transition matrix $\bm{T}$ representing the proportion of the life jackets moving between the two stations. [2] On February 1st, before opening the park, the staff counted the number of life jackets and found there were $400$ life jackets at station $A$ and $500$ at station $B$. - Determine the number of life jackets expected to be at each station when the park opens on February 5th. Give your answer to the nearest whole number.[2] - - Show that the eigenvalues of $\bm{T}$ are $\lambda_1 = 1$ and $\lambda_2 = 0.62$. - Find a corresponding eigenvector for each eigenvalue from $\textbf{part (c) (i)}$. - Hence express $\bm{T}$ in the form $\bm{T} = \bm{PDP}^{-1}$. [6] - Show that $\bm{T}^n = \dfrac{1}{2}\begin{bmatrix} 1+ (0.62)^n & 1 - (0.62)^n \\ 1-(0.62)^n & 1+(0.62)^n \end{bmatrix}$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. [2] - Hence, find an expression for the number of life jackets in station $A$ after $n$ days, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$ [3]

    &\answer{= 0.81\hspace{0.05em}\%}

title: Question 1
content: The ocean pressure, $P$, under sea level can be modelled by the function $$ P(D) = \dfrac{D}{10}+1 $$ where $D$ is the distance in metres below sea level and $P$ is measured in atmospheres. A submarine cruising near the surface is submerged according to the function $$ D(t) = 10+5t $$ where $t$ is measured in minutes and $D$ is the distance the submarine is below sea level, measured in metres. - Find the composite function $P\circ D$ and explain what it means in the context of this question[3] - Find and interpret $(P\circ D)(10)$.[2]
markScheme:
- The composite function can be expressed as

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ D) (t) &= P(D(t)) \rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &= P(10+5t)\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &= \dfrac{10+5t}{10}+1 \rule[-4.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{= 2+\dfrac{t}{2}}\rule[-5.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  This composite function represents the ocean pressure (in atmospheres) outside the submarine at time t minutes.
- Substituting $t=10$ in (1), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  (P\circ D)(10)&=2+\dfrac{10}{2}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{4mm}\\
  &\hspace{0.28em}\answer{=7}\rule[-3.5mm]{0pt}{9mm}\end{aligned}
  $$

  This result means that after 10 minutes, the ocean pressure outside the submarine is 7 atmospheres.

title: Question 9
content: The radius of a cylindrical container with height $x$ cm is $$ \begin{aligned} r(x) = \dfrac{56}{x},\qquad 4\leq x\leq 16\end{aligned} $$ - Find the range of $r$.[3] The function $r^{-1}$ is the inverse function of $r$. - - Find $r^{-1}(8)$. - Interpret the answer to part (b) (i) in context. - Find the range of $r^{-1}$.[4]
markScheme:
- A sketch of $r(x)$ shows that the minimum value is found where $x=16$ and the maximum value is found where $x=4$.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/47ec87ad-d03d-40ae-b070-86ca7d589f8a/images/5e3319c6-2a5b-4f5e-9751-0736b3e580f0/AI1002a.PNG)


  Evaluating $r$ at the endpoints of its domain, we get

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  r(4) &= \dfrac{56}{4} = 14 \\[11pt]
  r(16) &= \dfrac{56}{16} = 3.5
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore the range of $r$ is $\answer{3.5 \leq r \leq 14}$
- 
  - Let $r^{-1}(8)=a$. This implies that $r(a)=8$.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \dfrac{56}{a} &= 8 \\[11pt]
    a &= \dfrac{56}{8} \\[11pt]
    a &= 7
    \end{align*}
    $$

    $r(7)=8$ and therefore $\answer{r^{-1}(8) = 7}$
  - When the radius of the container is $8\,$cm the height is $7\,$cm
  - Using the definition of a function inverse, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \text{range of $r^{-1}$} &= \text{domain of $r$}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Therefore the range of $r^{-1}$ is $\answer{4 \leq r^{-1} \leq 16}$
