title: Question 19
content: The function $f$ is defined by $f(x) = \dfrac{7x-24}{x-2}$, for $-3 \leq x \leq 12$, $x \neq 2$. - Find the range of $f$. [3] - Find an expression for the inverse function $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] - Write down the range of $f^{-1}$. [1]
markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $f$, by using G.D.C., we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8f054f1a-9ea4-4053-a5d1-6fa515e9906d/images/1a167d6a-7e1e-416a-b9c6-b49067e30e6a/6790d3e3a83e5ec16eb602a4d64032370f792ab9.svg)


  Hence, using the $y$-coordinates of A and B, we find
$\answer{(-\infty, 6] \cup [9, \infty)}$
- If we solve the equation $x = (f\circ f^{-1})(x)$ for
$y = f^{-1}(x)$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x &= f(f^{-1}(x)) \\[12pt]
  x &= f(y) \\[12pt]
  x &= \dfrac{7y-24}{y-2} \\[12pt]
  x(y-2) &= 7y-24 \\[12pt]
  xy-2x &= 7y-24 \\[12pt]
  xy-7y &= 2x-24 \\[12pt]
  y(x-7) &= 2x-24 \\[12pt]
  y &= \dfrac{2x-24}{x-7} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace*{-3.01em}\answer{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{2x-24}{x-7}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The range of $f^{-1}(x)$ is equal to the domain of $f(x)$, therefore
the
range of $f^{-1}(x)$ is
$\answer{-3 \leq f^{-1}(x) \leq 12\text{ , } f^{-1}(x) \neq 2}$

title: Question 1
content: Brendan is training for a long distance bike race. In week $1$ of his training he cycled $22\,$km. In week $2$ he cycled $34\,$km. This pattern continues, with him cycling an extra $12\,$km per week. The distances Brendan cycled in the first $5$ weeks of training is shown in the following table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fbe76ea2-07bd-426c-90a3-5ad8f53713f4/images/02dbbd15-959b-4291-aa53-aba9944b29df/Screenshot%202023-08-31%20at%202.15.24%20PM.png) - Calculate how far he cycles in the $17$th week of his training. [3] - In total how far has he cycled after $17$ weeks? [2] - Find the mean distance per week he cycled over 17 weeks. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the formula for the $n$th term of an arithmetic sequence

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      u_{17}&=22+(17-1)\times 12\\[6pt]
      u_{17}&=214
  \end{align*}
  $$

  He cycled $\answer{214\,\text{km}}$ in the $17$th week.
- Using the formula for the sum of $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      S_{17}&=\frac{17}{2}(2\times22+(17-1)\times12)\\[6pt]
      S_{17}&=2006
  \end{align*}
  $$

  After $17$ weeks he cycled a total of $\answer{2006\,\text{km}}$.
- Using the formula for the mean

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      &=\frac{22+34+46+...+214}{17}\\[6pt]
      &=\frac{2006}{17}\\[6pt]
      &=118
  \end{align*}
  $$

  His mean distance per week over the $17$ weeks of training was $\answer{118 \text{ km}}$ per week.

title: Question 2
content: The $15$th term of an arithmetic sequence is $21$ and the common difference is $-4$. - Find the first term of the sequence. [2] - Find the $29$th term of the sequence. [2] - Find the sum of the first $40$ terms of the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_{15} + (n-15)d$ with $n = 1$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_{15} + (1-15)d \\[6pt]
  &= 21 + (1-15)(-4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 77}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 29$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{29} &= u_1 + (29-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 77 + (29-1)(-4) \hspace{0.4em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -35}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 40$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.8em} S_{40} &= \dfrac{40}{2}(2u_1 + (40-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{40}{2}(2(77) + (40-1)(-4)) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= -40}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 3
content: Only one of the following four sequences is arithmetic and only one of them is geometric. $$ \begin{array}{rcccccl} a_n &=& 1,\,5,\,10,\,15,\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& c_n &=& 1.5,\,3,\,4.5,\,6,\,\dots \\[12pt] b_n &=& \dfrac{1}{2},\,\dfrac{2}{3},\,\dfrac{3}{4},\,\dfrac{4}{5},\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& d_n &=& 2,\,1,\,\dfrac{1}{2},\,\dfrac{1}{4},\,\dots \end{array} $$ - State which sequence is arithmetic and find the common difference of the sequence. [2] - State which sequence is geometric and find the common ratio of the sequence.[2] - For the geometric sequence find the exact value of the eighth term. Give your answer as a fraction. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  a_2-a_1 &\neq& a_3-a_2 &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& c_2-c_1 &=& c_3-c_2 \\[12pt]
  5-1 &\neq& 10-5 &&& 3-1.5 &=& 4.5-3 \\[12pt]
  4 &\neq& 5 &&& 1.5 &=& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  b_2-b_1 &\neq& b_3-b_2 &&& d_2-d_1 &\neq& d_3-d_2 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2}{3}-\dfrac{1}{2} &\neq& \dfrac{3}{4}-\dfrac{2}{3} &&& 1-2 &\neq& \dfrac{1}{2}-1 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{6} &\neq& \dfrac{1}{12} &&& -1 &\neq& -\dfrac{1}{2}
  \end{array} \vspace{0.75em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{c_n}$
is arithmetic and
$\answer{d = 1.5}$
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  \dfrac{a_2}{a_1} &\neq& \dfrac{a_3}{a_2} &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& \dfrac{c_2}{c_1} &\neq& \dfrac{c_3}{c_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{5}{1} &\neq& \dfrac{10}{5} &&& \dfrac{3}{1.5} &\neq& \dfrac{4.5}{3} \\[12pt]
  5 &\neq& 2 &&& 2 &\neq& 1.5 \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  \dfrac{b_2}{b_1} &\neq& \dfrac{b_3}{b_2} &&& \dfrac{d_2}{d_1} &=& \dfrac{d_3}{d_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{2/3}{1/2} &\neq& \dfrac{3/4}{2/3} &&& \dfrac{1}{2} &=& \dfrac{1/2}{1} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3} &\neq& \dfrac{9}{8} &&& \dfrac{1}{2} &=& \dfrac{1}{2}
  \end{array} \vspace{0.5em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{d_n}$
is geometric and
$\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{2}}$
- Using the $n$th term formula $d_n = d_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d_8 &= d_1r^{8-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 2\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^{8-1} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{64}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 4
content: An arithmetic sequence has $u_1 = 40$, $u_2 = 32$, $u_3 = 24$. - Find the common difference, $d$. [2] - Find $u_8$. [2] - Find $S_8$. [2]
markScheme:
- The common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 32 - 40 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -8}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 8$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.0em} u_8 &= u_1 + (8-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 40 + (8-1)(-8) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -16}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(u_1 + u_n)$
with $n = 8$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_8 &= \dfrac{8}{2}(u_1+u_8) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{8}{2}(40+(-16)) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 96}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 5
content: Only one of the following four sequences is arithmetic and only one of them is geometric. $$ \begin{array}{rcccccl} a_n &=& \dfrac{1}{3},\,\dfrac{1}{4},\,\dfrac{1}{5},\,\dfrac{1}{6},\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& c_n &=& 3,\,1,\,\dfrac{1}{3},\,\dfrac{1}{9},\,\dots \\[12pt] b_n &=& 2.5,\,5,\,7.5,\,10,\,\dots &\,\hspace{4em}\,& d_n &=& 1,\,3,\,6,\,10,\,\dots \end{array} $$ - State which sequence is arithmetic and find the common difference of the sequence. [2] - State which sequence is geometric and find the common ratio of the sequence.[2] - For the geometric sequence find the exact value of the sixth term. Give your answer as a fraction. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  a_2-a_1 &\neq& a_3-a_2 &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& c_2-c_1 &\neq& c_3-c_2 \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1}{4}-\dfrac{1}{3} &\neq& \dfrac{1}{5}-\dfrac{1}{4} &&& 1-3 &\neq& \dfrac{1}{3}-1 \\[12pt]
  -\dfrac{1}{12} &\neq& -\dfrac{1}{20} &&& -2 &\neq& -\dfrac{2}{3} \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  b_2-b_1 &=& b_3-b_2 &&& d_2-d_1 &\neq& d_3-d_2 \\[12pt]
  5-2.5 &=& 7.5-5 &&& 3-1 &\neq& 6-3 \\[12pt]
  2.5 &=& 2.5 &&& 2 &\neq& 3
  \end{array} \vspace{0.75em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{b_n}$
is arithmetic and
$\answer{d = 2.5}$
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rclc|crcl}
  \dfrac{a_2}{a_1} &\neq& \dfrac{a_3}{a_2} &\,\hspace{0.5em}\,&\,\hspace{0.5em}\,& \dfrac{c_2}{c_1} &=& \dfrac{c_3}{c_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{1/4}{1/3} &\neq& \dfrac{1/5}{1/4} &&& \dfrac{1}{3} &=& \dfrac{1/3}{1} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &\neq& \dfrac{4}{5} &&& \dfrac{1}{3} &=&\dfrac{1}{3} \\[12pt] \hline
  &&&&&&& \\
  \dfrac{b_2}{b_1} &\neq& \dfrac{b_3}{b_2} &&& \dfrac{d_2}{d_1} &\neq& \dfrac{d_3}{d_2} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{5}{2.5} &\neq& \dfrac{7.5}{5} &&& \dfrac{3}{1} &\neq& \dfrac{6}{3} \\[12pt]
  2 &\neq& 1.5 &&& 3 &\neq& 2
  \end{array} \vspace{0.5em}
  $$

  Hence
$\answer{c_n}$
is geometric and
$\answer{r = \dfrac{1}{3}}$
- Using the $n$th term formula $c_n = c_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  c_6 &= c_1r^{6-1} \\[8pt]
  &= 3\left(\dfrac{1}{3}\right)^{6-1} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \dfrac{1}{81}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 10
content: A tennis ball bounces on the ground $n$ times. The heights of the bounces, $h_1, h_2, h_3, \dots,h_n,$ form a geometric sequence. The height that the ball bounces the first time, $h_1$, is $80$ cm, and the second time, $h_2$, is $60$ cm. - Find the value of the common ratio for the sequence. [2] - Find the height that the ball bounces the tenth time, $h_{10}$. [2] - Find the total distance travelled by the ball during the first six bounces (up and down). Give your answer correct to $2$ decimal places. [2]
markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{h_2}{h_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{60}{80} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 0.75} \hspace{2.75em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $h_n = h_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 10$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_{10} &= h_1r^{10-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 80(0.75)^{10-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 6.01\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{h_1(1-r^n)}{1-r}$
with $n=6$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{total distance} &= 2S_6 \\[12pt]
  &= 2\bigg[\dfrac{h_1(1-r^6)}{1-r}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= 2\bigg[\dfrac{80(1-0.75^6)}{1-0.75}\bigg] \hspace{2.4em} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{\approx 526.09\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 11
content: The table shows the first four terms of three sequences: $u_n$, $v_n$, and $w_n$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5a6e3e9a-7fb2-470e-9158-094a41eb3d33/images/74fa1661-4759-4c81-bc1b-8a688c7642eb/c39694c1cf7513ffce115791e6b0f1c54c230963.svg) - State which sequence is - arithmetic; - geometric. [2] - Find the sum of the first $50$ terms of the arithmetic sequence. [2] - Find the exact value of the $13$th term of the geometric sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{v_n}$
  - $\answer{w_n}$

- The common difference of the arithmetic sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= v_2 - v_1 \hspace{0.75em} \\[6pt]
  &= 24 - 12 \\[6pt]
  &= 12\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2v_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=50$,
  we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} S_{50} &= \dfrac{50}{2}(2v_1 + (50-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{50}{2}(2(12) + (50-1)(12)) \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 15\hspace{0.15em}300}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The common ratio of the geometric sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{w_2}{w_1} \hspace{2.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{24}{12} \\[12pt]
  &= 2\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the $n$th term formula
$w_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 13$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.1em} w_{13} &= u_1r^{13-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 12\hspace{0.05em}(2)^{13-1} \hspace{3.8em} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 49\hspace{0.15em}152}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 13
content: The third term, $u_3$, of an arithmetic sequence is $7$. The common difference of the sequence, $d$, is $3$. - Find $u_1$, the first term of the sequence. [2] - Find $u_{60}$, the $60$th term of sequence. [2] The first and fourth terms of this arithmetic sequence are the first two terms of a geometric sequence. - Calculate the sixth term of the geometric sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_3 + (n-3)d$ with $n = 1$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_3 + (1-3)d \hspace{0.4em} \\[6pt]
  &= 7 + (1-3)(3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_3 + (n-3)d$ with $n = 60$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{60} &= u_3 + (60-3)d \\[6pt]
  &= 7 + (60-3)(3) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 178}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/077c6738-9c33-4398-a027-bb1140fcb037/images/9d0d8334-9630-4b77-b911-39471a73ca86/ad62ab3f954984b454acd9a772d836d707c86a2f.svg)


  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 6$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_6 &= u_1r^{6-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 1(10)^{6-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 100\hspace{0.15em}000} \hspace{3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 14
content: A $3$D printer builds a set of $49$ Ei$\text{f}$fel Tower Replicas in different sizes. The height of the largest tower in this set is $64$ cm. The heights of successive smaller towers are $95$ % of the preceding larger tower, as shown in the diagram below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/127e3c5d-3aa2-4475-aa67-2df200261d2b/images/6ef94ba8-4b62-4fb0-9b70-993b9ddba3a5/AI110.PNG) - Find the height of the smallest tower in this set. [3] - Find the total height if all $49$ towers were placed one on top of another. [3]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 64$ and the
common ratio $r = 0.95$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n=49$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{49} &= u_1r^{49-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 64(0.95)^{49-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.46 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1-r^n)}{1-r}$
with $n=49$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} S_{49} &= \dfrac{u_1(1-r^{49})}{1-r} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{64\hspace{0.05em}(1-0.95^{49})}{1-0.95} \\[12pt]
  &\approx 1176.33 \\[16pt] 
  &\answer{\approx 1180 \text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 19
content: The fifth term, $u_5$, of a geometric sequence is $375$. The sixth term, $u_6$, of the sequence is $75$. - Write down the common ratio of the sequence. [1] - Find $u_1$. [2] The sum of the first $k$ terms in the sequence is $292\hspace{0.15em}968$. - Find the value of $k$. [3]
markScheme:
- The common ratio is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  r &= \dfrac{u_6}{u_5} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{75}{375} \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 0.2} \hspace{3.2em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5r^{n-5}$ with $n = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 &= u_5r^{1-5} \\[6pt]
  &= 375(0.2)^{1-5} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 234\hspace{0.15em}375}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $S_k = 292\hspace{0.15em}968$ for $k$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{u_1(1-r^k)}{1-r} &= 292\hspace{0.15em}968 \hspace{9.3em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{234\hspace{0.15em}375(1-(0.2)^k)}{1-0.2} &= 292\hspace{0.15em}968 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{6.6em} \answer{k = 8} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 20
content: Bruno rides his bike to school each morning. During the first minute, he travels $160$ metres. In each subsequent minute, he travels $80\,\%$ of the distance travelled during the previous minute. The distance from his home to school is $750$ metres. Bruno leaves his house at $8$:$30$ am and must be at school by $8$:$40$ am. - Verify that Bruno will not arrive at school on time. [3] Bruno realises that if he can increase the distance he travels each minute, from $80\,\%$ of the distance travelled during the previous minute to $k\,\%$, he will make it to school on time. - Determine the minimum value of $k$, given that Bruno still travels $160\,\text{m}$ in the first minute. [3]

title: Question 22
content: The fifth term, $u_5$, of an arithmetic sequence is $25$. The eleventh term, $u_{11}$, of the same sequence is $49$. - Find $d$, the common difference of the sequence. [2] - Find $u_1$, the first term of the sequence. [2] - Find $S_{100}$, the sum of the first $100$ terms of the sequence. [2]
markScheme:
- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n=11$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{11} &= u_5 + (11-5)d \\[6pt]
  49 &= 25 + (11-5)d\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{5.8em}\answer{d = 4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_5 + (n-5)d$ with $n=1$, we
find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.7em} u_1 &= u_5 + (1-5)d \\[6pt]
  &= 25 + (1-5)(4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1+(n-1)d)$
with $n = 100$,
  we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.1em} S_{100} &= \dfrac{100}{2}(2u_1+(100-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{100}{2}(2(9)+(100-1)(4)) \\[10pt]
  &\answer{= 20\hspace{0.15em}700}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 26
content: The sum of the first $n$ terms of an arithmetic sequence, $S_n = u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \dots + u_n$, is given by $S_n = 2n^2 + n$. - Write down the values of $S_1$ and $S_2$. [2] - Write down the values of $u_1$ and $u_2$. [2] - Find $d$, the common difference of the sequence. [1] - Find $u_{10}$, the tenth term of the sequence. [2] - Find the greatest value of $n$, for which $u_n$ is less than $100$. [3] - Find the value of $n$, for which $S_n$ is equal to $1275$. [2]
markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rlcrl}
  S_1 &= 2(1)^2 + 1 &\text{and}& S_2 &= 2(2)^2 + 2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3} &\,\hspace{5em}\,& &\answer{= 10}
  \end{array} \hspace{2.2em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  
  \begin{array}{rlcrl}
  u_1 &= S_1 &\text{and}& u_2 &= S_2 - S_1 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3} &\,\hspace{5em}\,& &=10-3 \\[6pt]
  &&&&\answer{= 7}
  \end{array}
  $$

- The common difference is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d &= u_2 - u_1 \\[6pt]
  &= 7 - 3 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 10$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.35em} u_{10} &= u_1 + (10-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 3 + (10-1)(4) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 39}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.7em} u_n &< 100 \\[9pt]
  u_1 + (n-1)d &< 100 \\[9pt]
  3 + (n-1)(4) &< 100 \\[10pt]
  n &< 25.3 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence
the greatest value of $n$ such that $u_n < 100$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{n = 25} \hspace{2.3em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $S_n = 1275$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) &= 1275 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2(3) + (n-1)(4)) &= 1275 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.9em} \answer{n = 25} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 27
content: The Australian Koala Foundation estimates that there are about $45\hspace{0.15em}000$ koalas left in the wild in $2019$. A year before, in $2018$, the population of koalas was estimated as $50\hspace{0.15em}000$. Assuming the population of koalas continues to decrease by the same percentage each year, find: - the exact population of koalas in $2022$; [3] - the number of years it will take for the koala population to reduce to half of its number in $2018$. [3]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  2018:\hspace{0.5em} u_1 &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  2019:\hspace{0.5em} u_2 &= 45\hspace{0.15em}000\end{aligned}
  $$

  The
common ratio of the sequence is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.1em} r &= \dfrac{u_2}{u_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{45\hspace{0.15em}000}{50\hspace{0.15em}000} \\[12pt]
  &= 0.9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.5em} 2022:\hspace{0.5em} u_5 &= u_1r^{5-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 50\hspace{0.15em}000(0.9)^{5-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 32\hspace{0.15em}805}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $u_n = 25\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1r^{n-1} &= 25\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  50\hspace{0.15em}000(0.9)^{n-1} &= 25\hspace{0.15em}000\end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.5em} n \approx 7.58 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\[2pt]
  $$

  Hence it will take
$\answer{7.58 \text{ years}}$
for the koala population to reduce to half of its number in $2018$.

title: Question 34
content: Bill is planning to hike the Appalachian trail, a $3\hspace{0.1em}600$ kilometre long walking track along the east coast of the USA. Bill plans to hike $2.1$ kilometres on the first day, then increase his distance by $200$ metres every day, so that on day $2$ he will hike $2.3$ kilometres, on day $3$ he will hike $2.5$ kilometres and so on. - Calculate how far Bill will hike on day 90. [2] - Determine how many days it will take Bill to hike the entire Appalachian trail. [3] - Hence determine how far Bill will have to hike on the final day. [1] Bill can hike at an average speed of 5 kilometres per hour. - Determine how long Bill will have to hike for on the final day.[2] Bill’s friend Stephen starts hiking the Appalachian trail on the same day but uses a different strategy to Bill. Stephen will hike 1 kilometre on the first day, then increase his distance by $3\%$ per day, so that on day 2 he will hike 1.03 kilometres, on day 3 he will hike 1.0609 kilometres and so on. - Calculate how much further Bill hikes than Stephen on day 90. [3] - Determine the day on which Stephen passes Bill. [3] - Calculate how many days earlier Stephen finishes the entire trail than Bill. [2]

title: Question 35
content: A ball is dropped from the top of the Eiffel Tower, $324$ metres from the ground. The ball falls a distance of $4.9$ metres during the first second, $14.7$ metres during the next second, $24.5$ metres during the third second, and so on. The distances that the ball falls each second form an arithmetic sequence. - - Find $d$, the common difference of the sequence. - Find $u_5$, the fifth term of the sequence. [2] - Find $S_6$, the sum of the first $6$ terms of the sequence. [2] - Find the time the ball will take to reach the ground. Give your answer in seconds correct to one decimal place. [3] Assuming the ball is dropped another time from a much higher height than of the Eiffel Tower, - find the distance the ball travels from the start of the $10$th second to the end of the $15$th second. [3] The Eiffel Tower in Paris, France was opened in $1889$, and $1.9$ million visitors ascended it during that first year. The number of people who visited the tower the following year ($1890$) was $2$ million. - Calculate the percentage increase in the number of visitors from $1889$ to $1890$. Give your answer correct to one decimal place. [2] - Use your answer to part (e) to estimate the number of visitors in $1900$, assuming that the number of visitors continues to increase at the same percentage rate. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - We have $u_1 = 4.9$ and $u_2 = 14.7$.
Hence the common difference is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &= u_2 - u_1 \hspace{1.4em} \\[6pt]
    &= 14.7 - 4.9 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 9.8\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with $n = 5$,
we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.4em} u_5 &= u_1 + (5-1)d \\[6pt]
    &= 4.9 + (5-1)(9.8) \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 44.1\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.4em} S_6 &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2u_1 + (6-1)d) \\[4pt]
  &= \dfrac{6}{2}(2(4.9) + (6-1)(9.8)) \\[9pt]
  &\answer{= 176\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $S_n = 324$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d) &= 324 \\[3pt]
  \dfrac{n}{2}(2(4.9) + (n-1)(9.8)) &= 324 \\[6pt]
  n &\approx 8.13 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.45em} \answer{n \approx 8.1\text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 9$ and $n=15$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{15} - S_9 &= \bigg[\dfrac{15}{2}(2u_1 + (15-1)d)\bigg] - \bigg[\dfrac{9}{2}(2u_1 + (9-1)d)\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \bigg[\dfrac{15}{2}(2(4.9) + (15-1)(9.8))\bigg] - \bigg[\dfrac{9}{2}(2(4.9) + (9-1)(9.8))\bigg] \\[11pt]
  &\answer{= 705.6\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the percentage increase formula
$\%\hspace{0.2em}\textbf{increase} = \dfrac{v_\mathrm{E}-v_\mathrm{S}}{v_\mathrm{S}}\times 100\hspace{0.05em}\%$
with $v_\mathrm{S} = 1.9$ and $v_\mathrm{E} = 2.0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \%\hspace{0.2em}\textbf{increase} &= \dfrac{2.0-1.9}{1.9}\times100\hspace{0.05em}\% \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.3\hspace{0.05em}\%}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $v_1 = 1.9$ million
and the common ratio $r =  1.0526$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $v_n = v_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n = 12$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.8em} v_{12} &= v_1r^{12-1} \\[6pt]
  &= (1.9\text{ million})(1.0526)^{12-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 3.34 \text{ million}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 38
content: Georgia is on vacation in Costa Rica. She is in a hot air balloon over a lush jungle in Muelle. When she leans forward to see the treetops, she accidentally drops her purse. The purse falls down a distance of $4$ metres during the first second, $12$ metres during the next second, $20$ metres during the third second and continues in this way. The distances that the purse falls during each second forms an arithmetic sequence. - - Write down the common difference, $d$, of this arithmetic sequence. - Write down the distance the purse falls during the fourth second. [2] - Calculate the distance the purse falls during the $13$th second. [2] - Calculate the total distance the purse falls in the first $13$ seconds. [2] Georgia drops the purse from a height of $1250$ metres above the ground. - Calculate the time, to the nearest second, the purse will take to reach the ground. [3] Georgia visits a national park in Muelle. It is opened at the start of $2019$ and in the first year there were $20\hspace{0.15em}000$ visitors. The number of people who visit the national park is expected to increase by $8\hspace{0.1em}\%$ each year. - Calculate the number of people expected to visit the national park in $2020$. title: Question 40
content: Let $u_n = 4n+1$, for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - - Using sigma notation, write down an expression for $u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \dots + u_{20}$. - Find the value of the sum from part (a) (i). [4] A geometric sequence is defined by $v_n = 9\times 4^{n-1}$, for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Find the value of the sum of the geometric series $\displaystyle\sum_{k = 1}^5\hspace{0.1em}v_k$.[2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Using sigma notation, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \dots + u_{10} &= \sum_{k=1}^{20} u_k \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{20} (4k+1)} \hspace{8em}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we rewrite $u_n = 4n+1$ in the form $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.5em} u_n &= 5 + (n-1)(4)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence $u_n$ is
an arithmetic sequence with the first term $u_1 = 5$ and
the common difference $d = 4$.
    Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=20$
    we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \sum_{k=1}^{20} (4k+1) &= S_{20} \\[3pt]
    &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2u_1 + (20-1)d) \\[9pt]
    &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2(5) + (20-1)(4)) \\[14pt]
    &\answer{= 860}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.3em} v_1 &= 9 \hspace{3em} [\text{the first term}] \\[9pt]
  r &= 4 \hspace{3em} [\text{the common ratio}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{v_1(r^n-1)}{r-1}$ with
$n=5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{k = 1}^5 9\times 4^{k-1} &= S_5 \\[3pt]
  &= \dfrac{v_1(r^5-1)}{r-1} \hspace{3.4em}  \\[9pt]
  &= \dfrac{9\hspace{0.05em}(4^5-1)}{4-1} \\[15pt]
  &\answer{= 3069}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 41
content: Landmarks are placed along the road from London to Edinburgh and the distance between each landmark is $16.1$ km. The first milestone placed on the road is $124.7$ km from London, and the last milestone is near Edinburgh. The length of the road from London to Edinburgh is $667.1$ km. - Find the distance between the fifth milestone and London. [3] - Determine how many milestones there are along the road. [3]
markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence with $u_1 = 124.7$ and $d = 16.1$.
Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with
$n = 5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.6em} u_5 &= u_1 + (5-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 124.7 + (5-1)(16.1) \\[6pt]
  &= 189.1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the the distance between the fifth
milestone and London is
$\answer{189\hspace{0.25em}\text{km}}$
- If we solve the inequality $u_n < 667.1$ for the largest value of
$n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 + (n-1)d &< 667.1 \\[6pt]
  124.7 + (n-1)(16.1) &< 667.1 \\[6pt]
  n &< 34.7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  n &= 34 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence there are
$\answer{34}$
milestones along the road.

title: Question 42
content: Elon is challenged to a speed climb at a local mountain. He has to reach a height of $400$ metres above the ground within four hours. Elon knows he can climb $150$ metres in the first hour. Due to increasing tiredness, each hour he can only climb $75\hspace{0.05em}\%$ of the height climbed in the previous hour. - Verify that Elon reaches his target height of $400$ metres in four hours.[2] The mountain has a height of $650$ metres. Elon decides to attempt to climb to the summit. - Determine whether he can reach the summit of the mountain if he continues climbing, given his increasing tiredness. Justify your answer.[2] On a different day, Elon climbs with energy snacks, which help to reduce his tiredness as he climbs. On this day, Elon again climbs 150 metres in the first hour, but then $k\hspace{0.05em}\%$ of the height he climbed in the previous hour, where $k > 75$. - Calculate the minimum value of $k$, given that on this day Elon is able to reach the summit. Give your answer as a percentage, to the nearest whole number.[3]
markScheme:
- We have a geometric sequence with first term $u_1 = 150$ and common
ratio $r = 0.75$. Hence, using the formula for the sum of the first
$n$ terms, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_{n} &= \dfrac{u_1(1-r^n)}{1-r} \\[12pt]
  S_{4} &= \dfrac{150(1-0.75^{4})}{1-0.75} \\[12pt]
  &\hspace{-1em}\answer{S_{4} \approx 410 \hspace{0.25em}\text{m} > 400 \hspace{0.25em}\text{m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the formula for the sum to infinity of a geometric
sequence, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_\infty &= \dfrac{150}{1 - 0.75}  \hspace{0.1em} \\[12pt]
  &= 600 \hspace{0.25em}\text{m} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Elon can't reach the summit since \(600 \hspace{0.25em}\text{m} < 650 \hspace{0.25em}\text{m}\).}\hspace{-0.15em}}$
- Using the formula for the sum to infinity of a geometric
sequence, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S_\infty &= \dfrac{150}{1 - r}  \hspace{0.1em} \\[12pt]
  \dfrac{150}{1 - r} &\geq 650 \hspace{0.1em} \\[12pt]
  r &\geq 0.76923... \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{The minimum value of k is 77\%.}}$

title: Question 43
content: Let $u_n = 5n-1$, for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - - Using sigma notation, write down an expression for $u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \dots + u_{10}$. - Find the value of the sum from part (a) (i). [4] A geometric sequence is defined by $v_n = 5\times 2^{n-1}$, for $n \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. - Find the value of the sum of the geometric series $\displaystyle\sum_{k = 1}^6\hspace{0.1em}v_k$.[2]
markScheme:
- 
  - Using sigma notation, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_1 + u_2 + u_3 + \dots + u_{10} &= \sum_{k=1}^{10} u_k \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= \displaystyle\sum_{k=1}^{10} (5k-1)} \hspace{8em}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - If we rewrite $u_n = 5n-1$ in the form $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$, we
have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.5em} u_n &= 4 + (n-1)(5)\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence $u_n$ is
an arithmetic sequence with the first term $u_1 = 4$ and
the common difference $d = 5$.
    Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with
$n=10$
    we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \sum_{k=1}^{10} (5k-1) &= S_{10} \\[3pt]
    &= \dfrac{10}{2}(2u_1 + (10-1)d) \\[9pt]
    &= \dfrac{10}{2}(2(4) + (10-1)(5)) \\[14pt]
    &\answer{= 265}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8.3em} v_1 &= 5 \hspace{3em} [\text{the first term}] \\[9pt]
  r &= 2 \hspace{3em} [\text{the common ratio}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{v_1(r^n-1)}{r-1}$ with
$n=6$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \sum_{k = 1}^6 5\times 2^{k-1} &= S_6 \\[3pt]
  &= \dfrac{v_1(r^6-1)}{r-1} \hspace{3.3em}  \\[9pt]
  &= \dfrac{5\hspace{0.05em}(2^6-1)}{2-1} \\[15pt]
  &\answer{= 315}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 44
content: Consider the sum $\displaystyle S = \sum_{k = 4}^l (2k-3)$, where $l$ is a positive integer greater than $4$. - Write down the first three terms of the series. [2] - Write down the number of terms in the series. [1] - Given that $S = 725$, find the value of $l$. [3]
markScheme:
- $\answer{5,\, 7,\, 9}$
- $\answer{l-3}$
- From part (a), we have an arithmetic sequence with the first term
$u_1 = 5$ and the common difference $d = 2$.
  Hence, using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = l-3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  S &= S_{l-3} \\[11pt]
  \hspace{4.5em}725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2u_1 + ((l-3)-1)d) \\[6pt]
  725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2(5) + (l-4)(2)) \\[6pt]
  725 &= \bigg[\dfrac{l-3}{2}\bigg](2 + 2l) \\[12pt]
  725 &= (l-3)(l+1) \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4.65em} \answer{l = 28} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

title: Question 49
content: On Wednesday Eddy goes to a velodrome to train. He cycles the first lap of the track in $25$ seconds. Each lap Eddy cycles takes him $1.6$ seconds longer than the previous lap. - Find the time, in seconds, Eddy takes to cycle his tenth lap. [3] Eddy cycles his last lap in $55.4$ seconds. - Find how many laps he has cycled on Wednesday. [3] - Find the total time, in minutes, cycled by Eddy on Wednesday. [4] On Friday Eddy brings his friend Mario to train. They both cycled the first lap of the track in $25$ seconds. Each lap Mario cycles takes him $1.05$ times as long as his previous lap. - Find the time, in seconds, Mario takes to cycle his fifth lap. [3] - Find the total time, in minutes, Mario takes to cycle his first ten laps. [3] Each lap Eddy cycles again takes him $1.6$ seconds longer that his previous lap. After a certain number of laps Eddy takes less time per lap than Mario. - Find the number of the lap when this happens. [3]
markScheme:
- We have an arithmetic sequence with the first term $u_1 = 25$ and
the common difference $d = 1.6$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1 + (n-1)d$ with
$n = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{10} &= u_1 + (10-1)d \\[6pt]
  &= 25 + (10-1)(1.6) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 39.4 \text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $u_n = 55.4$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 + (n-1)d &= 55.4 \hspace{10.1em} \\[6pt]
  25 + (n-1)(1.6) &= 55.4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.6em} \answer{n = 20 \text{ laps}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula
$S_n = \dfrac{n}{2}(2u_1 + (n-1)d)$ with $n = 20$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.1em} S_{20} &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2u_1 + (20-1)d) \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{20}{2}(2(25) + (20-1)(1.6)) \\[10pt]
  &= 804 \\[14pt]
  &\answer{= 13.4 \text{ minutes}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have a geometric sequence with the first term $v_1 = 25$ and the
common ratio $r = 1.05$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $v_n = v_1r^{n-1}$ with $n = 5$,
we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  v_5 &= v_1r^{5-1} \\[6pt]
  &= 25(1.05)^{5-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 30.4 \text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{v_1(r^n-1)}{r-1}$
with $n = 10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} S_{10} &= \dfrac{v_1(r^{10}-1)}{r-1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{25((1.05)^{10}-1)}{1.05-1} \hspace{0.7em} \\[12pt]
  &\approx 314.45 \\[15pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.24 \text{ minutes}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the inequality $u_n < v_n$ for the smallest value of $n$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_1 + (n-1)d &< v_1r^{n-1} \\[8pt]
  25 + (n-1)(1.6) &< 25(1.05)^{n-1} \\[9pt]
  11.7 &< n \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{n = 12 \text{th lap}} \hspace{0.7em}
  $$

title: Question 50
content: Sarah has started a 12 week training program to improve her cycling. She plans to cycle $100$ kilometres in the first week and, in each subsequent week, cycle $15$ kilometres further than she did the week before. - Calculate the distance she will cycle during the eighth week. She still plans to cycle $100$ kilometres in the first week, but in each subsequent week, she will cycle $k$ kilometres more than she did the week before. - Calculate the minimum integer value of $k$ required for Sarah to reach the target of $2\hspace{0.1em}500$ kilometres in 12 weeks.[3] As part of her training, each week Sarah performs a one kilometre time trial, in which she aims to cycle one kilometre as fast as she can. title: Question 52
content: A bouncy ball is dropped out of a second story classroom window, $5$ m off the ground. Every time the ball hits the ground it bounces $89$ % of its previous height. - Find the height the ball reaches after the $11$th bounce. [3] - Find the total distance travelled by the ball until it comes to rest. [3]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a0cfdc62-08c9-4a1b-9e66-0aaf65ecf30d/images/2dd17bda-67fe-40d1-bf3e-605278a03adc/8f1fbf3b941881b0c3497fa818d77dc32a216ccc.svg)


  Hence the height of successive bounces of the ball form a geometric
sequence with the first term $u_1 = 5(0.89)$ and the common ratio
$r = 0.89$.
  Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n = 11$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  u_{11} &= u_1r^{11-1} \\[6pt]
  &= [5(0.89)](0.89)^{11-1} \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1.39\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.8em} [\text{total distance travelled}] &= 5 + 10(0.89) +  10(0.89)^2 + 10(0.89)^3 + \cdots \\[11pt]
  &= 5 + 2[5(0.89) +  5(0.89)^2 + 5(0.89)^3 + \cdots] \\[12pt]
  &= 5 + 2S_{\infty} \hspace{3em} [u_1 = 5(0.89) \text{ \& } r = 0.89] \\[6pt]
  &= 5 + 2\bigg[\dfrac{5(0.89)}{1 - 0.89}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 85.9 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 53
content: A bouncy ball is dropped from a height of $2$ metres onto a concrete floor. After hitting the floor, the ball rebounds back up to $80$ % of it's previous height, and this pattern continues on repeatedly, until coming to rest. - Show that the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest can be expressed by $2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots$[2] - Find an expression for the total distance travelled by the ball, in terms of the number of bounces, $n$. [2] - Find the total distance travelled by the ball. [2]
markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/afeeb6e2-6980-4c78-946c-47a5ff25ff32/images/fb5415df-1c47-4d2f-8114-4ea15b45ac58/866fc824efe482d8b182d4c5b9e109a2fdbd4aca.svg)


  Hence the total distance travelled by the ball until coming to rest
is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of $n$ terms formula $S_n = \dfrac{u_1(1 - r^n)}{1-r}$
for a geometric sequence
  with $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} [\text{sum of $n$ terms of $(1)$}] &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1} \\[14pt]
  &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + \cdots + 4(0.8)^{n-1}\big] \hspace{1.3em} \\[8pt]
  &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4(1 - 0.8^{(n-1)})}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
  &= -2 + 20(1 - 0.8^{(n-1)}) \\[8pt]
  &= -2+20-20(0.8)^n(0.8)\\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 18 - 16(0.8)^n}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the sum of an infinite geometric sequence formula
$S_{\infty} = \dfrac{u_1}{1-r}$ with
  $u_1 = 4$ and $r = 0.8$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  &= 2 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots \\[14pt]
  &= -2 + \big[4 + 4(0.8) + 4(0.8)^2 + 4(0.8)^3 + \cdots\big] \\[8pt]
  &= -2 + \bigg[\dfrac{4}{1 - 0.8}\bigg] \\[8pt]
  &\answer{= 18 \text{ metres}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 4
content: Coral is a wildlife expert who tags flying fish and records their movement using an electronic device. The tagging device tells her the height of a fish relative to the water level, at any given time. She knows that the fish swim mostly in the water, but occasionally they fly (jump!) out of the water. The height is measured in metres and the time in seconds. If the height is negative the fish is under the water, if the height is positive the fish is flying. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/70f02a92-7870-456a-abea-c262c3ce2d2b/seagull.png) Coral notices one particular fish as it flies out of the water. The moment it re-enters the water the device begins tracking its height. At $2$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2.8\,$m; at $5$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2\,$m and at $11$ seconds the fish is also at a height of $-2\,$m. The height of the fish can be expressed as $H(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$. - - Write down the value of $d$. - Using the information given write down three equations involving $a$, $b$ and $c$. - Solve the system of equations to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4] From previous research, Coral knows that if a fish is flying for more than $1$ second then a seagull will attempt to catch it. - Use a justification to explain why a seagull will attempt to catch this fish. [4] At $t=9\,$s a seagull begins swooping down to catch the fish. Its height is given by $b(t)=-1.5t^2+27t-118$. - - Find the height at which the bird catches the fish. - Interpret the answer in the context of the problem. [4]

title: Question 9
content: A company manufactures cement, lime and mortar for construction projects. This question considers the validity of the company's claims regarding the weights of their products. Lime mortar is a mixture used in construction to reduce moisture in masonry. The mixture contains cement, lime and sand in the ratio $a:b:c$, where $a+b+c=17$. Cement costs $\$0.50$ per kilogram, lime costs $\$2.75$ per kilogram and sand costs $\$0.06$ per kilogram. Frank and Kevin have separately purchased $5a$ kilograms of cement, $5b$ kilograms of lime and $5c$ kilograms of sand each for their respective construction projects, in the correct ratio. They have made their purchases at different shops and therefore they have been charged different prices. The following table shows how much Frank and Kevin were charged per kilogram for each product, and the total amount they had to pay. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a98d123f-26a9-4287-a7fa-a3cc772e4d50/images/cd897c39-7e85-46b7-aed8-ada41f27dcdc/1169a.JPG) - - Determine a matrix equation of the form $\bm{A}\textbf{x}=\textbf{b}$ to represent the information given above.[2] - Hence, find the values of $a,b$ and $c$.[2] The cement is sold in $10\,$kg bags. The manufacturer claims that the weights of the bags, $C$, are such that $C\sim \mathrm{N}\left(10.2,0.1^2\right)$. - Calculate the probability that a randomly selected bag weighs less than $10\,$kg. Give your answer to four significant figures.[2] Bena needs a total of 200 kilograms and is given two options by the manufacturer. Option one: Twenty of the $10\,$kg bags so that $T_1=C_1+C_2+\cdots+C_{20}$ Option two: A single $200\,$kg “mega-bag” such that $T_2=20C$. - Determine - The distribution of $T_1$ .[3] - $\mathrm{P}(T_1>200)$[1] - Determine - The distribution of $T_2$ .[3] - $\mathrm{P}(T_2>200)$[1] - State which option Bena should choose, giving a reason.[1] Bena chooses option one. She suspects that the manufacturer’s claim is incorrect. To test this hypothesis, she weighs all twenty bags. If more than two bags weigh less than $10\,$kg, she will reject the manufacturer’s claim. - Calculate the significance level of Bena’s hypothesis test.[3] Bena finds that nine of her bags weigh less than $10\,$kg and lays a complaint with the manufacturer. The manufacturer concedes that they made an error, and while the mean weight of their bags is $10.2\,$ kg, in their claim they had accidentally written the variance as $0.1^2$, when it was in fact $0.1$. - Given this new information, find the probability that Bena could have made a type II error in her hypothesis test.[3] - If Bena had conducted her original hypothesis test with the correct information from the manufacturer, at the significance level found in part (f), determine the critical region for the test.[3] - Hence state whether she would have rejected the manufacturer’s claim. Justify your answer.[1]

title: Question 1
content: Jessica hits a tennis serve and the path of the ball can be modelled by the function $$ \begin{aligned} h(d) = 2+d-\dfrac{d^2}{5}\end{aligned} $$ where $h$ is the height above ground level in meters, and $d$ is the horizontal distance the tennis ball travels, also in meters. - Find the horizontal distance travelled by the ball when it hits the ground.[2] - Find the maximum height the ball reaches.[2] On her next serve, Jessica hits the ball harder and flatter, so that the ball reaches the same height as the previous serve, but travels twice as far. - Determine a new height function, $h_2$, that describes this trajectory.[2]
markScheme:
- If we sketch the graph of $h(d)$, for $d \geq 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5e48f29e-d2ab-494f-8541-86971485cc14/images/1dffd0c1-fe52-4cec-96e8-2a22889cea3f/2b33f5ae4640acb6d33c7265f26c197540d4968e.svg)


  Hence the horizontal distance travelled by the ball is:
$\answer{6.53\hspace{0.25em}\text{m.}}$
- From part (a) we see the maximum height is:
$\answer{3.25\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}.}$
- The trajectory $h_2$ is an horizontal stretch of $h(d)$ by a scale
factor of $2$.
  Therefore, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  h_2(d) &= 2+\dfrac{d}{2} - \dfrac{(d/2)^2}{5} \\[10pt]
  &\hspace{-2em}\answer{h_2(d)=2+\dfrac{d}{2}-\dfrac{d^2}{20}}\end{aligned}
  $$

title: Question 4
content:
Let $f(x) = \sin x$,  for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The
graph of $f$ is translated by
$\left(\hspace{-0.2em}\begin{matrix} \hspace{0.2em}p \\[2pt] -q \end{matrix}\right)$
to give the graph of a function $g$ that passes through the points
A$(0,-7)$ and B$(\pi, -5)$. It is given that $0 < p \leq 2\pi$.
Find the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
markScheme:
Since the graph of $f$ has been translated $p$ units in the direction of
the positive $x$-axis and $q$ units in the direction of the negative
$y$-axis, an expression for $g$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(x) &= f(x-p) - q \\[12pt]
&= \sin(x-p) - q \hspace{3.5em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the
coordinates of A$(0,-7)$ and B$(\pi, -5)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
-7 &= \sin(-p) - q  \\[12pt]
-5 &= \sin(\pi-p) - q \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore we have two expressions for $q$:

$$
\begin{align*}
q &= \sin(-p) + 7 \hspace{3em} [1]\\[12pt]
q &= \sin(\pi - p) + 5 \hspace{2em} [2]
\end{align*}
$$

Hence, we solve the following equation for $p$:

$$
\begin{align*}
\sin(-p) + 7 &= \sin(\pi - p) + 5
\end{align*}
$$

By using the G.D.C. we find $\hspace{0.5em}\tcbhighmath{p \approx 1.57 \text{ or }\dfrac{\pi}{2}}$
And substituting this value into equation [1], $\hspace{0.5em}\tcbhighmath{q = 6}$.

title: Question 5
content:
Let $f(x) = e^x$,  for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The
graph of $f$ is translated by
$\left(\hspace{-0.2em}\begin{matrix} -p \\[2pt] \hspace{0.2em}q \end{matrix}\right)$
to give the graph of a function $g$ that passes through the points
A$(0,1.5)$ and B$(\ln2, 2)$.
Find the value of $p$ and the value of $q$.
markScheme:
Since the graph of $f$ has been translated $p$ units in the direction of
the negative $x$-axis and $q$ units in the direction of the positive
$y$-axis, an expression for $g$ is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(x) &= f(x+p) + q \\[12pt]
g(x) &= e^{x+p} + q \hspace{3em} [\text{for $x \in \mathbb{R}$}]\\
\end{aligned}
$$

Hence, using the coordinates of A$(0,1.5)$ and B$(\ln2, 2)$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
1.5 &= e^{p} + q \\[12pt]
2 &= e^{\ln2+p} + q \hspace{0.5em} \\
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore we have two expressions for $q$:

$$
\begin{align*}
q &= 1.5 - e^{p} \hspace{3em} [1]\\[12pt]
q &= 2 - e^{\ln2+p} \hspace{2em} [2]
\end{align*}
$$

Hence, we solve the following equation for $p$:

$$
\begin{align*}
1.5 - e^{p} &= 2 - e^{\ln2+p}
\end{align*}
$$

By using the G.D.C. we find $\hspace{0.5em}\tcbhighmath{p \approx -0.693}$
And substituting this value into equation [1], $\hspace{0.5em}\tcbhighmath{q = 1}$.
